Good morning REMOVED,
 
 Your email was forwarded to us by REMOVEDs. Christina. To help us better understand
 which age program you are interested in, please visit our website and complete a
 profile demographic form. This will provide us with the information we need and
 allow you to schedule a tour of our facility.
 
 Once you‚Äôve completed the profile, our system will notify us, and we‚Äôll be able
 to share more specific details regarding availability and potential start dates.
 
 Please let us know if you have any questions or need assistance completing the
 form.
 
 Looking forward to hearing from you.
 
 Gayle Nicholas-Dortch
 
 Executive Director
 
 14230 Spartina Ct
 
 Jacksonville, FL 32224
 
 Tel (904) 821-0085
 
 Fax (386) 675-0828
 
 From: Jacksonville II, FL - The Goddard School
 <Jacksonville2FL@goddardschools.com>
 Sent: Tuesday, October 7, 2025 8:58 AM
 To: gayle <gayle@jaxgs.com>; jenni <jenni@jaxgs.com>; kat <kat@jaxgs.com>

 On Tue, Oct 7, 2025 at 3:10 PM Lori Rogers <lorirogs76@gmail.com> wrote:
 
  Hello, I am so sorry your daycare closed down, seems like a lot are closing
  down and quickly.
  I have 1 spot that came available to start as early as 10/14. I‚Äôm open from
  7:30-5:30 and provide all food and milk with lunch. Nap time is between
  12-3pm. Drop off is between 7:30-9am and pick ups are between 3-5:30pm. We do
  many activities in the morning and even go to the park that‚Äôs next door while
  our back yard is getting new fencing and grass. I do have dogs but they don‚Äôt
  interact with the kids (Basset Hounds sleep all day) and my old cats just stay
  away.
  The kids have cubbies that hold extra clothes, diapers and their nap blanket.
  I‚Äôll let you know when I need anything with plenty of notice. I do help with
  potty training as long as parents have started at home first.
  How did you hear about my daycare?
  Lori

Hello!
 Thank you for your message. It has been an honor to have been part of the Little
 Owl Community. My last day with Little Owl School was Thursday, July 31, 2025.
 If you have any questions regarding classroom matters, please email Darryl
 Redick, Director of Program, Teaching and learning at
 darrylr@littleowlschool.org.
 For any enrollment questions, please email Grace McGlynn, Director of
 Operations, at gracem@littleowlschool.org
 If you are a student inquiring about practicum placement or classroom
 observations, please email Darryl at darrylr@littleowlschool.org
 For all other questions or concerns, please email littleowl@littleowlschool.org
 and a member of the Little Owl staff will connect you with the appropriate
 person.
 Thank you and have a wonderful day.
 Warm regards,
 Michelle Ramirez

 ------ Attachment PottyTraining.pdf -----
  Carden Conservatory Preschool
  Potty Training Success
  Applying the Carden Philosophy to Potty Training
 Philosophy
 
 Each child is a unique individual. A successful program is sensitive to the child‚Äôs social,
 emotional, and physical needs. Our developmentally appropriate potty training program
 focuses on the individual needs of your family, helping you and your child enjoy a
 successful experience in an encouraging and nurturing environment.
 
 The Child‚Äôs Approach
 
 ‚ÄúThe Child has eyes that see, and ears that hear. He has experiences and reaches
 conclusions‚Äù ‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúFor a long time his achievement is fragmentary. The teacher (and the
 parent) must accept the child‚Äôs approach (and the child‚Äôs pace).‚Äù
  Excerpted from: Quality Teaching, Successful Learning, Mae Carden
 
  As true as these words are for academic learning, so are they for potty training.
 Make sure that the child sees and hears positive, encouraging words about going on the
 potty. Let him see the restroom, the Big Kid pants, and the joys of being diaper free.
 Remember that for some this can be a long term goal, for others it may happen quickly.
 
 Thinking From the Inside Out
 
  - Be responsive to effort and individual expression
  - Know when to praise, too much is cloying. Do not over praise or underestimate.
  - Maintain sure growth as the goal
  - Be a participant in the process.
 Excerpted from: Quality Teaching, Successful Learning, Mae Carden
 
  Purpose
 
  The purpose of potty training is to the child to gain control of his/her body‚Äôs
  functions. It is a time of great success and achievement. Mastering this new skill will
  help build your child‚Äôs self-esteem and enhance his positive self image.
  ‚ÄúIs it time to give up the diapers?‚Äù
  Children at this age are so in need of control that if a child senses that using the potty
  is something that you are choosing for him, then it gives them a focus to rebel against.
  Potty training must at least give the appearance of being the child‚Äôs choice. This
  means that parents must wait until the child is willing to ‚Äúditch‚Äù the diapers.
 
  Signs of Readiness
  o Does your child stay dry at least two hours a day?
 
  o Is your child‚Äôs bowel movement regular and predictable?
 
  o Does your child let you know with words of gestures that they
  are about to urinate or have a bowel movement?
 
  o Does your child ask to use the potty?
 
  Procedure
 Carden takes a self-mastery approach to potty training. Implementing this program
 requires that children be ready to willingly participate in the process. Willingness and
 readiness on the part of the child are necessary to create a positive experience. Only if
 the child finds the experience pleasing will it be successful for the family.
 
  1. The first step is knowledge. Exposing your child to the idea of toilets and their
  functions eliminates uncertainty.
  2. The second step is encouragement. Encourage the child‚Äôs natural interest in the
  potty and its use.
  3. The third step is security. Let your child know that he is loved wherever and
  whenever he chooses to go on the potty, and even if he does not choose to do so.
  4. The fourth step is opportunity. Take your child to the potty and offer the chance
  to go regularly.
  5. The fifth step is reinforcement. Whether the child succeeds on the potty or not,
  his effort should be rewarded.
 
 Our staff will work with each family to develop a plan that offers opportunity and
 reinforcement which is consistent and manageable both at home and school.
 Each plan will be designed to offer an incentive that interests the child and is acceptable
 to the parent. The consistency of the plan between home and school is essential to
 success. The child should realize that both his parents and his teachers support and
 encourage his efforts. A daily recognition by the parents of the child‚Äôs efforts during the
 school day is integral to success, as is recognition by the teacher of the child‚Äôs ongoing
 effort at home. We must all work together to create a consistent, positive plan for the
 child‚Äôs effort to be successful.
 
 Presenting the Opportunity
 Children will be escorted to the restroom in groups every hour and a half. ( 7:30, 9:00,
 10:30, 12:00, 3:00, 4:30, 6:00) Each child will be asked if he needs or would like to go
 on the potty. Children will be encouraged, but not forced to go on the potty. Visiting the
 restroom and seeing their peers using the facilities will encourage the children to try in
 their own time.
 
 Children will be given positive feedback, verbal and non-verbal. They will receive
 encouragement for each success, but no criticism. Children who do not ‚Äúgo‚Äù on the potty
 should not be made to feel that they have failed, but encouraged to seek the next
 opportunity for success. Your child will proudly present to you his/her daily Potty
 Training Chart for your encouraging words.
 
 Reinforcing the Idea
 Each family will be encouraged to carefully consider the type of reinforcement that they
 choose. Each child will respond best to rewards that are of interest to him. If your child
 is fond of insects, bug stickers might be best for your daily chart. If she loves flowers, a
 flower stamp might be best for you. Remember, the most vital encouragement and
 reinforcement that your child needs is praise and a smile from his/her loved ones as you
 discuss the Potty Training Chart he shows you each day.
 
  Suggestions for Reinforcements
  a. Stickers
  b. Stamps
  c. Treasure Chest Items
  d. Choosing a story
  e. Being Line Leader
 
 How can Parents and Teachers help children feel competent as they master this skill?
 
  o By offering modified toilet seats secured to the adult-size seats
 
  o By insuring that someone is available to assist any needs the child
  may have
  o By providing step stools to make sinks and paper towels accessible
 
 Carden will work hand in hand with the parents to ensure your child‚Äôs success in potty
 training. Our staff is available to discuss any concerns that you may have concerning
 your child‚Äôs progress. Our goal is to provide a safe and nurturing environment that will
 help your child to be successful in the potty training process. Each child will receive
 immediate positive reinforcement for every attempt the child makes through a sticker
 chart that will help to outline the child‚Äôs progress. Parents are encouraged to discuss and
 praise their child each day for the progress your child has made. Together, we can make
 the potty training experience positive and rewarding for the child.
 
 ------ End of attachment -----

 Carden Conservatory

  Program
  Carden Conservatory 2 Year Old, Preprimary and Junior
  Kindergarten Program
 Our Purpose:
 To have children enjoy:
  v Companionship, music, literature, and pre-academic
  concepts in an atmosphere that is pleasant, calm, and
  purposeful.
  v Opportunities for the development of independence and
  self-discipline.
  v A balance between active/quiet activities and
  structure/balance.
 
 To have children cultivate:
  v A pleasant speaking voice.
  v An appreciation of beauty.
  v A cheerful attitude toward life.
 
 To help children adjust socially by:
  v Getting along with peers and adults.
  v Taking responsibility for their own behavior.
  v Developing a positive attitude.
  v Developing conversational ability.
  v Experiencing consideration for others by learning to
  delight in their successes.
  v Learning to be interested in their activities.
  v Showing concern for others when something
  unfortunate occurs.
 
 To assist in the development of pre-academic concepts and
 skills:
  v To develop dexterity with scissors and writing
  instruments.
  v To practice taking turns.
  v To increase attention on directed tasks.
  v To learn to make choices of good consequences.
  v To facilitate creative play.
  v To develop the ability to recall and follow a sequence of
  instructions.
  v To develop concepts of numbers.
  v To develop familiarity with letters and sounds.
 
 Guidance in personal behavior:
  v Learning to share.
  v Learning to accept responsibility.
  v Learning to take turns.
  v Learning to wait patiently and good-naturedly.
  v Learning to be generous and kind.
 
 Guidance in physical development exercises:
  v Play involving physical fitness.
  v Rhythms that strengthen muscles.
  v Attainment of ease in movement.

  Carden Conservatory
 
  Carden Conservatory
  Uniform Information
 
 Carden Conservatory is proud of its uniform policy. We believe that a student‚Äôs
 appearance has a direct impact on his or her attitude, behavior, and academic
 performance at school. Uniforms foster school pride and are praised as a
 convenience by our parents. Uniforms also instill a sense of modesty and decorum
 and help students to realize that there is an appropriate dress for the proper time
 and place. Uniforms also serve to reduce distractions from the real purpose of
 school, which is to learn, not make fashion comparisons. This uniform policy is
 designed to free children to appreciate the deeper qualities of their classmates.
 Because children‚Äôs attention is not as focused on superficial, surface differences,
 there is greater acceptance among peers and discourages ‚Äúcliquish‚Äù behavior.
 
 Monday and certain assembly days are our Official Carden Uniform Days. On all
 other days our optional uniforms may be worn. Students are required to wear their
 Carden Conservatory maroon shirts on Fridays and field trip days. Sandals and
 backless shoes are not permitted. Children in grades 5th-8th are required to dress
 out for P.E.
 
 All uniforms are available through Vicki Marsha Uniforms.

Hello! Thank you for your interest in our school!
 
 Island Village Montessori School‚Äôs 12 Acre campus is home to over 500 children
 in grades Pre-K - 8th.
 
 Our Charter program is part of the Sarasota County School District
 serving students in Kindergarten ‚Äì 8^th grade, and is the county‚Äôs only FREE
 Montessori Charter School.
 
 Our private, tuition based, preschool program is open to children ages 3-5.
 Tuition information is found on our website by visiting
 www.IslandVillage.org/earlychildhood
 
 As is customary with Montessori learning environments our preschool program
 hosts students in a variety of ages. IVMS preschool children are
 typically ranging in ages from early 3 ‚Äì 5yrs old. All children must be fully
 potty trained before attending IVMS.
 
 Students enjoy an open concept classroom with a variety of workspaces,
 Montessori learning materials and three opportunities a day to play outdoors.
 Lessons focus on academics as well as social and emotional learning. The variety
 of ages and abilities allows for collaborative learning and the flexibility to
 meet each child where they are at individually while encouraging their growth.
 The goal is to prepare them not just to be a student but to also be a joyful
 learner.
 
 We would love to have an opportunity to show you our campus and answer specific
 questions you may have. I am offering tours every Tuesday morning at 9am and
 the first Friday of each month at 4pm. Please let me know if you would like to
 join an upcoming tour!

 Owner/Operator:
 My name is Jennifer Houston; I have enjoyed being a licensed family child care provider
 through the state of Massachusetts and the Department of Early Education & Care
 (EEC) since August of 1996. After 13 years as a travel agent that included 8 years in
 corporate management, came the birth of my third child. After Jake was born I wanted
 to be home with my children. Along with my love of children and the need for an income,
 becoming a child care provider seemed the perfect option. My REMOVED has been a
 Waltham Firefighter since November of 1994 and our family grew to 4 children. Jesse
 was born in 1991, Ayme in 1994, Jake in 1996 and Tessa in 1999. What a wonderful
 and rewarding job this has turned out to be.
 My work began as a contracted provider for Newton Family Day Care System in
 October of 1996 where I worked with a diverse group of families. I began work as an
 independent provider in April of 2007. Myself and both of my assistants are certified in
 child CPR and First Aid. Our journey in education as childcare providers continues
 through workshops and child development training that are a requirement for our state
 license. Palissa, Debbie and I make a great team. The loving and nurturing care we
 provide has made our family childcare home a continued success. It is our absolute
 privilege and pleasure to care for your children.
 
 Certified Lead Assistant:
 Debra Close
 Hello, my name is Debra Close. I grew up in West Newton until marriage. We then
 moved to Waltham right on the West Newton line and started my own family child care
 business in 1983. I have 2 adult children Nicole & Kellie and 2 grandchildren Colt and
 Rivi. I began my own child care business so that I could be home and raise my 2 girls
 and have an income. I began my work as part of a daycare system out of West Newton
 and worked through them for 33 years. The last 12 years I was an independent
 provider for a small family child care home: up to 6 children. I retired from my own
 daycare during the pandemic but was still not ready to stop working with children. I met
 Jennifer when we both worked for the daycare system so I have known her since she
 began in 1996. I started working with Jennifer as a lead assistant when child care
 reopened after the pandemic. I absolutely love working here! My whole life I have
 worked with children, even as a teenager. It is my absolute passion. I am very grateful
 to still be working doing what I love! I am not sure yet when I will really retire, right now
 I am content and delighted to be working here 2 - 3 days a week. Who knows, maybe I
 will still be here with my walker some day!
 
 Certified assistant:
 Donna McMahon
 My name is Donna McMahon, I have been married for 42 years. I am a mother of 3 sons, Chad,
 Chris , Colby and I have 1 grandson Lincol. I have lived in Needham for the past 35 years and
 have worked as Chairwoman for the Health & Safety Committee for 8 years on a volunteer
 basis, for the renovations of the Needham High School. Most of my life has been spent working
 with children either at schools, babysitting, sports and many other events. I recently retired from
 Home Depot Corporate Division as our jobs were eliminated during the Covid emergency. Since
 my retirement I decided to look in the area of Child Care as this has been my passion. I began
 working with Jenn Houston in October of 2022. I work anywhere between 25-35 hours per
 week job sharing with Debbie Close. Jenn runs an excellent program and it shows not only
 through her daily interactions with the children but how excited they are to come everyday.
 
 My Philosophy/My Promise:
 I strive to enhance the emotional and physical wellbeing of each and every child. I
 promise to provide a safe, comfortable, nurturing, stimulating, fun and educational
 environment in my home with a semi-structured day plan. Activities will include free
 playtime, structured playtime, large motor skill playtime, small motor skills activities,
 story time, creative play, arts and crafts, music and dance activities, nature and ecology
 awareness, nutrition, cultural activities, and other educational yet fun activities. I will
 also provide nutritious meals and snacks, and encourage good personal hygiene skills
 and manners.
 Television is occasionally used during regular care hours and then only to watch
 programs that are musical or educationally oriented and appropriate for even the
 youngest viewers. I reserve the very limited use (1/ 2 hour at the most) of television for
 those days of extreme weather when outside activities are prohibited.
 My philosophy in teaching is geared towards social readiness. Through a mixture of
 guided and undirected creative play, children in my care will have the opportunity to
 learn about color, shapes, textures, numbers, letters, animals, seasons, feelings,
 senses, nutrition, personal hygiene, manners, basic science and math concepts, and
 creative concepts such as "pretend" play, art, music, drama, dance, independence,
 kindness and respect of one another. These may sound like lofty goals for infants,
 toddlers, and preschoolers, but most children learn all of these things and more through
 creative educational play. I do not believe in pushing any child to learn at an accelerated
 rate, and will not make a child feel pressured to achieve developmental milestones. By
 providing a fun and safe environment, I believe the children will learn at their own
 appropriate pace.
 
 1. HOUSTON FAMILY CHILD CARE.
 Houston Family Child Care is a family child care home licensed under the
 Massachusetts Department of Early Education and Care (EEC). For this purpose, ‚Äúchild
 care‚Äù means care for children who are in need of personal services, supervision,
 age-appropriate activities and education. I accept children aged from 4 weeks through 3
 years of age or until they move on to preschool.

 3. "SCHOOL YEAR" HOURS/SCHEDULE
 A. Hours of operation
 My home is open Monday through Friday from 7:00 am until 4:00 pm sharp
 Children will be contracted for hours not to exceed those of operation and may not
 include 15 minute increments.
 Contracted hours may begin between the hours of 7a and 8am and end between
 the hours of 3 and 4pm.
 The total hours per week must be rounded up to the half or
 full hour. I do not offer a part time daily schedule; I will however consider a part time
 weekly schedule of a minimum of 3 full days with the minimum of 21 hours.
 
 B. SUMMER HOURS/SCHEDULE 2026
  The school year ends Friday June 26th 2026 at 12 noon. No lunch will be served
 on this day.
 If you have a child moving on to preschool during this time period you may
 choose to end your contract with me. You may also choose to send your child
 during the transitioning weeks in August of 2026 to begin some consistency in
 their schedule.
 
 4. FEES FOR 2025/26 All checks should be made payable to Jennifer
 Houston.
 Full time: Care contracted for 30 or more hours per week at the rate of $13.00 per hour
 on a set scheduled time slot. Part time: Care contracted for less than 30 hours per week
 at the rate of $15.00 per hour on a set scheduled time slot. No refunds are given due to
 late arrivals, early departures, parent vacations or child illness. Late arrivals do not
 constitute late departures. *A two week non refundable deposit is due upon signing this
 contract per child and each subsequent contract/s per new year.
 
 Full time care: $_______ per week
 Part time care: $_______ per week

 A. Late fees. A grace period of up to 5 minutes will be given at no charge along with a

 times per month. After that a charge of $20.00 per 5 minutes will be charged to the
 following month's billing.
 B. Overtime fees. Prearranged overtime care may be requested at the rate of $25.00
 per hour again with no 15 minute increments (rounded up the half or full hour).
 All overtime fees should be paid at time of service in cash only.
 5. PAYMENT SCHEDULE. For consistency and record keeping I bill for the

 per week should be paid separately in cash by Friday or by the end of your contracted
 hours/days.

 7. ARRIVALS AND DEPARTURES.
 There is a sign in/out sheet that is used for attendance. Please send your child
 dressed for the day (weather appropriate) and adhere to your contracted arrival and
 departure times. I cannot stress this enough, please arrive on time for pick up and drop
 off. A text advising me that you are late is courteous and polite; however, it still does not
 excuse the fact that you are late.
 Late arrivals are disruptive to our daily schedule. If you need to make an
 appointment for your child you must do so that our day is not interrupted. All
 appointments must be made with every effort so that your child is picked up directly
 after lunch by 12:15 or after a nap by 2:40 at the earliest. Once a child has been picked
 up they may not return for the day. Absolutely no pick up will be allowed between the
 hours of 12:15-2:40 unless it is an emergency. This is nap time. It is disruptive to the
 entire group for us to wake a child during these hours. Please make goodbyes brief (no
 more than a couple of minutes) the longer you prolong departure the harder it is for your
 child. Please do not ‚Äúsneak out‚Äù, never leave without telling your child goodbye.
 Transitions can be very stressful for any child and or parent. Some days may be easy
 while others may be more difficult, it is extremely important to keep these transactions
 brief especially on the more difficult days.
 
 8. ABSENCE POLICY. Full fee will be charged for all absences due to illness,
 early departure or parent vacation. Please make a phone call or text me to advise if a
 child will be absent each day. Any closings required by the State of Massachusetts
 and/or the CDC for COVID or any new/unknown viruses will be charged as a contracted
 day.
 
 9. CHILD ILLNESS POLICY. Provider reserves the right not to provide care
 for a child who has an acute illness or whose condition, in the Provider‚Äôs objective
 judgment, poses a direct threat to the health and safety of that child or other children or
 staff in the program. Please do not bring your child if he/she is sick; I can only care for
 
 children with mild cold-like symptoms (clear runny nose, slight cough, and no fever). Per
 Health Department regulations children will not be allowed to attend the daycare if they
 exhibit symptoms such as:
 *Rash *Fever (100 F. higher) *Excessive cold and/or cough (yellow or green mucus
 uncontrolled cough) *Vomiting *Diarrhea *Lice or nits *Pink eye or conjunctivitis (must
 be on medication for a full 24 hours) *Coxsackie virus *Unusual drowsiness *Persistent
 or excessive crying *Communicable diseases (chicken pox, Rosella, conjunctivitis,
 mumps, measles, strep throat and influenza). A child must be fever free for a full 24
 hours (without medication) before returning to daycare. If it is determined that we have a
 Norovirus or stomach flu making its way through the daycare your child must remain
 home for a minimum of 72 hours before returning to daycare as long as they are
 symptom free. If a child does become ill during daycare hours - parents will be
 contacted and the child should be removed as soon as possible. Once the child is
 removed from daycare due to illness, they may not return until after the required
 minimum hours home or until they are no longer ill.
 If a child is sent home due to illness, this will be considered an absence in accordance
 with paragraph 8.
 In addition, if a child is on an antibiotic for the very first time they may not return
 to daycare until they have been administered 3 full doses of that medication.
 
 10. MEDICATION: Provider can administer medication if needed, but only if the
 Medication Consent Form has been signed. All medicine must be in the original
 container with the child's name clearly written on it. Written instructions with the child's
 name, dose and times need to accompany the medication. I cannot administer any over
 the counter medicine during daycare hours. This includes but is not limited to: Tylenol,
 Children‚Äôs Motrin, Baby Aspirin or Cold Medication. If your child needs any of these
 medications they should NOT be in daycare.
 
 11. MEDICAL EMERGENCIES: In the case of a serious accident or
 sudden illness requiring medical attention, the following procedures are followed:
 1) Immediate medical attention is given: CPR or FIRST AID
 2) A phone call is made to 911.
 2) Child's parents (or emergency contacts) are called.
 3) Child and health records are taken to emergency service at Newton Wellesley
 Hospital or Hospital of choice.
 4) In all cases, an emergency report is completed and a copy is given to parents as well
 as the EEC.
 * It is extremely important, especially in instances of illness or emergency that the
 emergency contact information is up to date and all information is correct. Please report
 any changes immediately to keep your emergency contact information current.
 * For minor injuries like bumps and bruises, I will provide home first aid. If the injury is
 more serious, (I.e. needs stitches, broken bones, or dislocation, etc.) the parent will be
 notified immediately. Parents will be responsible for all costs involved in emergency
 medical treatment, including emergency transportation if required.
 
 12. SAFE ENVIRONMENT: Providers home is child-proofed by accordance
 with ECC license. I do not have any stairs. Poisons and medicines are stored in locked
 cabinets or out of reach of children. I have a carbon monoxide detector and several
 smoke detectors throughout the house. All electrical outlets are capped when not in
 use.
 
 12. ANIMAL HEALTH: I have 2 dogs; Skye a lab/shar pei mix & Odis is a treeing
 walker coon hound. Skye is a very shy dog and although she is great around the
 children she does not like to be touched or approached. Children are taught from the
 start not to touch the dogs. In general the dogs are asked to leave any space that we
 may currently be occupying. Parents: Please just ignore the dogs if they should be in
 our space at drop off or pick up, I do this so that my dogs learn not to approach any new
 people. All dogs are current with their vaccines.

 22. MEALS/FOOD: I provide a healthy breakfast for children arriving by 8:00am;
 lunch and a morning & afternoon snack. The children are offered the food, not forced to
 eat. Children who choose not to eat will not be served additional food until the next
 snack or mealtime. Please do not send food (half-eaten breakfasts, candy, snacks or
 gum) from home; this is strictly prohibited. At times I may have children in my care with
 food allergies, and even coming in contact with some foods can be life threatening. If
 your child has eaten something in the car prior to arrival please be sure their hands and
 face have been cleaned prior to entering the premises. We welcome food to be sent for
 special occasions and celebrations such as birthdays. Please check with me first about
 what foods may or may not be allowed. Any outside food must have the store bought or
 hand made ingredients clearly labeled. Parents need to supply Infant formula/breast
 milk and baby food until age 12 months or as soon as table food is introduced and they
 are no longer eating baby food.
 
 22a. BREAST MILK & BREAST FEEDING:
 All breast milk must be clearly labeled with a date and child‚Äôs name. All breast milk
 should come in freezer bags. While we absolutely encourage breastfeeding please do
 not expect to breast feed upon morning arrival, early departures and/or afternoon pick
 up. This is my personal home and my family may be present at any moment which may
 be awkward for them and possibly for you. Also, I just do not have the space to allow.
 Please breastfeed in your own home or in your car prior to morning arrival or after you
 have picked up your child for the day.

Hello REMOVED,
 
 Thank you for reaching out about the Early Learning Center (ELC). I listed some
 of the basic information below based on the previous school year and attached an
 application which you can simply complete and email back to me, and I will add
 your little one to the inquiry list. We have aligned our acceptances with the
 Pre-K-3 admissions process, reenrollment occurs in February, and newly admitted
 families receive word in early March should we have availability. We do give
 priority to Beauvoir as well as PECF (Beauvoir, NCS, STA, and Cathedral)
 employees and then siblings. It truly depends on the year as to affiliations
 and other community members who join us in the ELC. Unfortunately, at this time
 we are unable to accept students without the above affiliations, we will reach
 out to those on the inquiry list should that change. It is always best to
 complete the application and be added to the inquiry list just in case and if
 your little one will be four by August 31, 2026, please feel free reach out to
 the admissions office to apply for Pre-K. Please feel free to reach out if you
 have any questions as I am happy to arrange a time to connect.
 
 All the best, Colleen
 
 Hours: 7:30-4:00 for the school year
 
 School Year Tuition: $33,400
 
 Ages: 3 months-4 years (ratio 1-4 until the 3-year-old classroom when it is 1-8)
 and in our infants we typically have 1-3
 
 -Each class has Music, Spanish, & Library then in the 3-year-old class they also
 have STEAM as well as attend community meetings.
 -Families provide meals in the infant class and then lunch and snack are
 provided by the school.
 -We use a digital communication tool called Tadpoles to share daily information
 for all classes except the three-year-olds/ Cubs (food, bathroom, fun facts in
 this communication between home and school).

Hi REMOVED and REMOVED,
 Thank you for your email. We have a toddler spot available immediately. If you'd
 like to visit, we are interviewing families over the next few weeks. If you're
 interested in visiting, please answer the questions below.
 Below are some questions that help us to decide who we may be able to provide
 care for. Because some questions are of a personal or medical nature, you are
 not required to answer them. However, the questions help us to get an idea of
 what families would be a good fit for our daycare.
 
 1. How old is your child?
 
 2. How many adults and children are living in your household? Please provide
 names for all members in the household.
 
 3. What is your current child care situation? What past childcare have you
 had? Are you on the waiting list at any other daycares?
 
 4. Do you have a plan for care if your child is sick?
 
 5. What days and hours would you like?
 
 6. When would you like to start care?
 
 7. Where are you located and how long have you lived in the area?
 
 8. Does your child have any known food or environmental allergies?
 
 9. Have the adults and children over the age of 6 months old in the house
 received a covid-19 vaccine?
 
 10. How often does your family travel for work or vacations?
 
 11. How did you hear about us?
 
 We‚Äôd also love to hear any other information you‚Äôd like to share about your
 family such as hobbies, holidays celebrated or values specific to you.
 
 Please note that we have family members with suppressed immune systems, so if
 anyone in your family is feeling ill, experiencing symptoms or had a recent
 exposure to anyone who is sick, please let us know and we will be happy to
 reschedule your viewing of our daycare.
 
 Our website is also an excellent source of additional information including
 tuition and hours: junebabydaycare.com

Hi REMOVED,
 
 Thank you for reaching out to Adventure Kids Playcare! We completely understand
 how stressful unexpected closures can be.
 
 We‚Äôre a drop-in childcare center, so we don‚Äôt require long-term enrollment, but
 we do ask families to make reservations once registration is completed ‚Äî this
 helps us manage ratios and space since we can get busy at times.
 
 If you‚Äôd like, we can schedule a quick tour or info visit so you can meet our
 team and see the center before your first drop-in.
 
 You may reply to this email or call with a date and time that works best for
 you for a tour.
 
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
  üéìCare Rate
 
 There is a $40 annual family registration fee (membership), which includes your
 membership benefits. Once your account is set up, you can conveniently make
 reservations online at any time.
 
 With membership:
 
 üçºInfants (6 weeks‚Äì17 months): $16/hour
 
 üß∏ Toddlers (18 months‚Äì12 years): $14/hour
 
 ‚è∞ Hours of Operation
 
  * Monday‚ÄìThursday: 7:00 AM ‚Äì 8:00 PM
 
  * Friday: 7:00 AM ‚Äì 12:00 AM
 
  * Saturday: 9:00 AM ‚Äì 12:00 AM
 
  * Sunday: Closed
 
 Please note that as an alternate care facility, no child can be in care at one
 AKP location for more than 5 consecutive days or 15 days per calendar month.
 
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
  üìù Complete Registration Before Arrival
 
 On your first visit, and each year, we require new paperwork to be completed
 online for your child(ren).
 
 To help us prepare for your visit, please complete your child‚Äôs registration
 online prior to your first day by clicking the link below:
 
 üîó Register Here
 
 Important: If registration is not complete prior to arrival, we will not be able
 to check your child in. Completing this at the center may take up to 20 minutes.
 
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
  üíâ Immunization Records
 
 We must have current immunization records on file for:
 
  * All children not currently enrolled in school
 
  * If your child is in a public school or another daycare, please provide
  the school name, address, and phone number
 
  * If exempt, you must provide the original State Vaccine Exemption Form
 
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
  üéí What to Bring
 
 Infants (6 weeks‚Äì17 months)
 
  * Two complete changes of weather-appropriate clothing (including socks &
  shoes)
 
  * Prepared bottles and diapers for the day
 
  * Diaper ointment if needed (authorization form required)
 
  * Any medical or emergency supplies (epi-pens, etc., with required forms)
 
 Toddlers (18 months‚Äì3 years)
 
  * Two complete changes of clothing (including socks & shoes)
 
  * Small blanket and crib sheet for nap mat
 
  * Diapers and diaper ointment if needed (authorization form required)
 
  * Any medical or emergency supplies as needed
 
 Preschool / School-Age (3‚Äì12 years)
 
  * One complete change of clothing (including socks & shoes)
 
  * Toilet training supplies as needed
 
  * Any medical or emergency supplies (epi-pens, etc., with required forms)
 
 üëâ All items must be labeled with your child‚Äôs name to avoid loss or confusion.
 If your child has a food allergy, please provide a physician-signed emergency
 plan and all required medications at drop-off.
 
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
  üçΩ Meals & Snacks
 
 We provide meals and snacks throughout the day:
 
  * Breakfast: 8:00‚Äì9:00 AM
 
  * Lunch: 11:30 AM‚Äì1:00 PM
 
  * Dinner: 5:30‚Äì6:00 PM
 
  * Snacks: 10:00 AM, 3:00 PM, and 8:00 PM
 
 üç¥ Meals are $5 per child, per meal.
 ü•ú We are a nut-free facility, but you‚Äôre welcome to pack your child‚Äôs food as
 long as it‚Äôs nut-safe. We can refrigerate and reheat meals as needed.
 
 Best,
 Take a Virtual Tour or visit our Website

 The Mendham Cooperative Nursery School is all about community. During the
 course of the year, our director, teachers, and parents come together to make our
 school a truly special place. When you enroll in our cooperative preschool, you
 become a member of a warm, welcoming, and productive community, and it is
 our hope that you‚Äôll desire to participate as much as your time allows.
 
 We offer classes for all ages - we have a toddler program, 2s,
 3s and 4s. We are a play based preschool that makes
 learning exciting for all ages! Our littlest learners focus on
 socialization and learning how to share and cooperate. Our
 older students practice those important academic skills
 including listening and following directions in addition to
 learning letters, sounds and numbers. Fine and gross motor
 skills are always incorporated into fun and engaging activities.
 We strive to help all of our children to become independent
 and ready for kindergarten.
 
 The Co-op has visits from community helpers throughout the year and we take
 field trips to further enhance the curriculum. Our dedicated staff loves to come to
 work as much as the children love to come to school!

 Dear Parent,
 
 Thank you for your interest in Pine Village Preschool JP South Street! We are delighted that you
 are considering our childcare center for your child's educational journey. Pine Village Preschool is a
 highly respected Spanish Immersion School for Toddlers and Preschoolers with 10 locations in the
 Greater Boston area.
 
 Why Families Choose Pine Village Preschool
 Spanish Immersion: Our full immersion language school means that educators teach the regular
 curriculum exclusively in Spanish. While we speak Spanish 100% of the day, we support children in
 their native language (English) as needed so that they can learn Spanish gradually over time.
 
 Nutritious Meals and Snacks: We are one of the few childcare centers that operate our own private
 catering service with a focus on from-scratch, healthy, and nutritious meals. Children receive a hot
 lunch, two delicious snacks and milk throughout the day.
 
 Individualized Learning: Our play-based, Spanish immersion curriculum nurtures children‚Äôs social,
 emotional, cognitive, physical, and language development. This approach fosters exploration,
 curiosity, and creativity, allowing children to develop their interests and abilities at their own pace.
 
 Parent Communication: Via a mobile app, parents can view images and access daily updates on
 activities your child is enjoying, what they have eaten (and how much!), nap times, diaper changes,
 and more!
 
 Flexible Care: Pine Village Preschool supports each family‚Äôs unique schedule by offering both part-
 time and full-time care, along with flexible drop-off and pick-up times. Our full day is 8am to
 3:30pm and our extended day is 8am to 5:30pm.
 
 We look forward to welcoming you and your child to our family!

 safe and inclusive environment. The center aims to build a strong foundation in

 a few minutes to become familiar with this information, along with the Enrollment Application
 provided to you. On your Enrollment Application, you will be asked to acknowledge your receipt
 and agreement to the policies outlined in this handbook.
 
 This handbook has been written in accordance with the Department of Children & Families
 Office of Licensing Manual of Requirements as required for all childcare centers.
 
 Who We Are
 Precious People Early Learning Center was founded in 1997. We are family owned and we‚Äôve
 intentionally stayed small. We pride ourselves on establishing personal connections with
 families and giving each child the love and attention they need to blossom and grow.
 
 Precious People welcome children from age eighteen months through six years. Our programs
 include:
  ‚Ä¢ Chipmunk Class (Early Preschool)
  ‚Ä¢ Squirrel Class (Preschool)
  ‚Ä¢ Bunny Class (Full Day Kindergarten)
  ‚Ä¢ Extended Care (Before & After care)
  ‚Ä¢ Summer Camp (9 weeks filled with fun and sun)
 
 We are very flexible and are happy to work with you to create a schedule that works for your
 child and family. We offer enrollments from 3-5 days a week with three different pick-up times
 to meet your needs.
 
 Precious People is open fifty weeks per year. Our school year runs from Tuesday after Labor Day
 through the third week in June. Our summer Camp runs from the last week in June through the
 third week in August and enrollments for camp are done on a month-to-month basis.
 
 Dedication
 A positive early learning experience has an enormous impact on a child‚Äôs life. Each moment of
 early childhood is precious. We feel lucky to share those moments with your children and
 promise to fill their days with wonder, friendship, love and laughter. Precious People Early
 Learning Center is dedicated to the memory of Jack Antonio Sanzalone, the amazingly precious
 person who inspired our Founder to create our school.
 
  4
 REMOVEDion Statement
 Our mission is to provide a nurturing, safe, and stimulating environment where children can
 grow emotionally, socially, and intellectually through play-based learning and compassionate
 care. We partner with families to support each child‚Äôs unique developmental journey and foster
 a lifelong love of learning.
 
 Our Purpose
 Our purpose is to provide a nurturing, educational environment where children develop
 foundational skills for lifelong learning while giving parents peace of mind through exceptional
 care, long-tenured teachers, and communication.
 
 We believe childhood is precious and should be filled with wonder, joy, and discovery. We
 protect and celebrate this special time while gently preparing children for their next steps. We
 understand both the privilege and responsibility of caring for your children.
 
 Our Values
  a) Individualized Care ‚Äì Every child is known, loved, and supported as a unique individual.
  b) Play-Based Learning ‚Äì We nurture natural curiosity and growth through hands-on
  exploration.
  c) Family Partnership ‚Äì We work hand-in-hand with families to support each child‚Äôs
  development.
  d) Whole-Child Focus ‚Äì Emotional, social, physical, and cognitive needs are nurtured
  together.
  e) Safe & Loving Environment ‚Äì Our space is built on trust, warmth, and genuine care.
 
 Physical Environment
 Our center is located on a spacious property a few short blocks from the Westfield train station.
 Our three classrooms are bright, open and airy. Learning centers in each class are devoted to
 art, block play, dramatic play, math, science, reading and computers. We constantly update and
 improve our classrooms to ensure that our children have the highest quality learning materials.
 Outdoors, in our fully fenced, secure playground, there‚Äôs lots of great equipment and plenty of
 room to run and play. We believe a connection with nature and the outdoors is really important
 for young children, and we endeavor to have our children have the opportunity to play, learn
 and develop in our large playground, surrounded by trees and nature. We use certified
 playground organic materials to provide a safe environment for the children, and during
 Summer Camp, we have two Splash Days per week, giving the children a fun and active
 connection with the outdoors.
 
  5
 Our Teachers & Staff
 We are proud of our facility, but our staff makes Precious People really special. When you walk
 into our daycare, you will quickly feel the warmth and dedication from our incredible staff. We
 are not just a team; we're truly a family, and that feeling extends to every child and parent who
 joins us. Our three head of classroom teachers have each been with us for between 12 and 15
 years, a testament to their deep love for our school and the children we serve. This long-
 standing commitment means familiar faces for your little ones, consistent care, and a wealth of
 experience guiding their growth and development. They pour their hearts into creating a
 nurturing environment where every child feels safe, valued, and excited to learn each day.
 Kristine Monahan has been our director for four years and is also our Chipmunk Head Teacher.
 She is committed to ensuring that every child has the best possible school experience. Her door
 is always open.
 
 Our other wonderful teachers have also been with us for many years. They are dedicated,
 caring, educated professionals. Our teacher to child ratio exceeds all legal requirements and
 allows our teachers to provide each child with great personal attention and encouragement.
 
 Licensing & Accreditation
 Our school is state-licensed and regularly inspected to ensure everything meets or exceeds
 standards, including child-to-teacher ratios and safe facilities. Precious People is subject to
 inspection by state and local health, fire, licensing, and building agencies. Regulations and
 inspections pertain to staff qualifications, the facility and playground, nutrition, health and
 safety matters, record-keeping, and child-to-staff ratios. If you have any questions regarding
 licensing or regulations, please speak with the Director.
 
 Educational Programming
 Our Curriculum
 Our play-based curriculum is designed to help each of our young learners reach his or her full
 potential. This comprises:
  a. Child-Led Exploration
  i. Activities are guided by children's interests and choices.
  ii. Teachers observe and support rather than direct.
  iii. Encourages autonomy and decision-making.
  b. Developmentally Appropriate Practice
  i. Learning experiences match children's age and stage.
  ii. Focus on emotional, social, cognitive, and physical growth.
 
  6
  iii. Emphasizes process over product‚Äîhow children learn matters more than what
  they produce.
  c. Integrated Learning Through Play
  i. Combines academic concepts (like math, literacy, science) with playful
  experiences.
  ii. Examples: counting blocks, storytelling during pretend play and nature walks for
  science exploration.
  d. Social-Emotional Development
  i. Group play fosters cooperation, empathy, and communication.
  ii. Teachers model and support emotional regulation and conflict resolution.
  e. Safe and Stimulating Environment
  i. Classrooms are designed to invite play‚Äîopen-ended materials, cozy reading
  nooks, sensory stations.
  ii. Outdoor play is essential for physical development and imaginative exploration.
  f. Teacher as Facilitator
  i. Educators scaffold learning by asking open-ended questions and introducing new
  vocabulary.
  ii. They connect play to learning goals without interrupting the flow of play.
 
 Kindergarten
 Our accredited Kindergarten follows the Westfield Public School District curriculum and
 empowers students to develop the skills they need to excel in first grade and beyond. These
 days, children enter Kindergarten with lots of knowledge. Many have been in preschool for
 some time, are familiar with letters and numbers and are excited to learn more. Our objective at
 Precious People is to build on their knowledge to create a strong foundation in literacy, math,
 science and social studies. Our literacy program includes phonics, journal writing, reading
 groups and quality children‚Äôs chapter books read aloud. Our math program includes hands‚Äìon
 exposure to addition and subtraction, telling time, handling money, and the creation of charts,
 graphs and diagrams. Our science program includes class participation in exciting experiments.
 Our Kindergarten children graduate from Precious People extremely well prepared to enter first
 grade.
 
 Just as important, we help prepare our children for the difficult job of navigating society. Our
 Kindergartners are given the freedom and responsibility and making choices and acting on
 those choices in the classroom setting. They work together in small groups and are encouraged
 to participate in classroom discussions. When a conflict arises, our children are helped to
 
  7
 resolve it themselves. This helps our children learn the social skills and self-reliance that will be
 so important for the rest of their lives.
 
 Summer Camp
 Our fun-filled theme-based summer program runs from the last week of June through the third
 week of August and includes highlights like:
  ‚Ä¢ Visitors (e.g. petting zoo, puppet show, reptile man)
  ‚Ä¢ Outdoor arts and crafts
  ‚Ä¢ Twice weekly splash days
  ‚Ä¢ Enrichment activities such as Amazing Athletes
  ‚Ä¢ Theme based picnics.
 
 The School Day
 Your Child‚Äôs First Day
 Preparing for the first day of school can be exciting, but it can also be an overwhelming and
 anxious time ‚Äì we understand! We will work with you to make your child‚Äôs first day the best it
 can be. Don‚Äôt hesitate to share any concerns you have before that first drop-off. Each child is
 unique in their patterns and ease of adjustment to new situations. Parents will say good-bye to
 their child at the front door. Be sure to talk with the Teachers daily during the transition phase.
 A consistent daily schedule (arrival and departure routines) also helps children adjust to a new
 routine and environment.
 
 On the first day, we ask that you send in the items listed below. Please make sure to label each
 item with your child‚Äôs name. Your Precious Person will need:
  ‚Ä¢ Two sets of a seasonally appropriate change of clothes in a zip lock bag labeled with
  your child‚Äôs name
  ‚Ä¢ Breakfast (if needed and arriving before 8:40am) and lunch
  ‚Ä¢ A month‚Äôs supply of diapers and wipes (if applicable)
  ‚Ä¢ An updated immunization record AND universal health form
  ‚Ä¢ A water bottle
  ‚Ä¢ A nap time mat
  ‚Ä¢ A stuffed animal or extra blanket if you choose
 
 You are welcome to use our bicycle and stroller parking area at your own risk, this area is not
 securely monitored.
 
  8
 Transition to School
 It takes time for young child to become accustomed to new places, people and routines. To aid
 your child in making a smooth transition to the Center and to help him or her make a positive
 attachment to the teachers, we ask that Chipmunk families follow the procedure outlined
 below. These procedures may take a week or so. It is time well spent!
 
 Stage 1: Bring your child to school between 10:00 and 11:30. After saying a cheerful goodbye at
 the door, leave them for approximately 1 hour.
 
 Stage 2: Your child arrives at 9:00, stays in the school through lunch and is picked up at 12:30.
 
 Hours of Operation
 We are open from 7:00 a.m. until 5:30 p.m. Monday-Friday. Our academic day starts with circle
 time at 9:00 a.m. Please be sure that your child arrives at or before 9:00 a.m. This will give you
 a chance to touch base with your child‚Äôs teacher and allow our circle to proceed uninterrupted.
 
 Children here for morning preschool are picked up at 12:30, a full day ends at 3:00 and Children
 here for extended care must be picked up by 5:30. Please be prompt in picking up your child. A
 consistent pattern of late pick-ups may result in a late fee.
 
 School Closings
 Precious People Early Learning Center‚Äôs school year runs from the Tuesday after Labor Day until
 the third week in June. During the school year, we are closed:
  ‚Ä¢ MLK Jr Day
  ‚Ä¢ President‚Äôs Day
  ‚Ä¢ Good Friday
  ‚Ä¢ Easter Monday
  ‚Ä¢ Memorial Day
  ‚Ä¢ July 4th
  ‚Ä¢ Labor day
  ‚Ä¢ Thanksgiving and the Day After
  ‚Ä¢ Christmas Eve through New Year‚Äôs Day (inclusive)
  ‚Ä¢ We are also closed for the last week of August
 
 We delay or close for inclement weather when the Westfield Public Schools delay/close. Check
 the Westfield Public Schools Website or check your teacher‚Äôs email.
 
  9
 Late Pickup Policy
 A parent who does not arrive by the pick-up time for which they have paid for the month will be
 charged a $5.00 late fee plus $1.00 for every minute they are late arriving. Consistent late pick-
 ups could result in a child‚Äôs dismissal from the program or need to change enrollment to a later
 pick-up time. All late fees accumulated within a month will be paid as part of the following
 month‚Äôs tuition on the first day of the month.
 
 Nutrition
 Please bring your child‚Äôs lunch in a lunch box. A microwave and refrigerator are available in
 each room. Please advise us in writing if your child has food allergies. You are welcome to send
 your child in with breakfast if they are dropped off prior to 8:30am.
 
 Snacks will be provided to all children or you are welcome to send in your own.
 
 Toilet Learning
 Mastery of toilet learning gives child feelings of accomplishment, independence and self-
 confidence. Therefore, use of the potty is gently suggested at the times when the children wash
 their hands ‚Äì before snacks, when they come in from outdoor time, before lunch and after nap.
 Children are always praised for their attempts to use the potty, but are never belittled if they are
 not ready to do so.
 
 Rest Time
 Rest time for our Chipmunks is from 1:00 to 3:00, for our Squirrels from 1:00 to 2:30 and for our
 Bunnies from 12:45 to 1:30. Children are encouraged to nap but not required to do so. Children
 who are not napping after a reasonable amount of time will be given a quiet activity to do. If
 your child is enrolled for a 12:30 pick up but you would, on occasion, like them to stay at
 Precious People for rest time, it is a $20 fee per child per day.
 
 Screen Time & Technology
 Chipmunks have no sitting screen-time no matter the number of hours in care. In Squirrel and
 Bunny classrooms, sitting screen time is limited to 30 minutes except for an occasional holiday
 movie, but never exceeding one hour. Aftercare students may do short exercise/movement
 videos if they are physically active during the videos.
 
 Social Media
 This social media policy applies to parents and all staff of Precious People Early Learning Center.
 This policy includes (but is not limited to) the following technologies:
 
  10
  ‚Ä¢ Social networking sites (e.g. Facebook & Instagram) ‚Ä¢ Blogs ‚Ä¢ Discussion forums ‚Ä¢
  Collaborative online spaces ‚Ä¢ Media Sharing services (e.g. YouTube) ‚Ä¢ Micro-blogging
  (e.g. Twitter)
 
 As part of our duty to safeguard children, it is essential to maintain the privacy and security of
 all our families. We therefore require that:
  ‚Ä¢ Staff members may post photographs of students on Precious People‚Äôs social networking
  pages only with the express written consent of the child‚Äôs parent.
  ‚Ä¢ No photographs taken within the preschool setting or at preschool special events and
  outings with the children, are to be posted for public viewing, except those of your own
  child. Parents are advised that they do not have a right to photograph anyone else‚Äôs child
  or to upload photos of anyone else‚Äôs children. (This excludes those photographs taken by
  staff for use on the Precious People Facebook page and in other advertising material).
  ‚Ä¢ No public discussions are to be held, or comments made on social media sites regarding
  the school children, staff, or business (except appropriate use for marketing fundraising
  events) or that could be construed to have any impact on the school‚Äôs reputation or that
  would offend any member of staff or parent associated with the school.
  ‚Ä¢ Staff are advised to manage their personal security settings to ensure that their
  information is only available to people they choose to share information with.
  ‚Ä¢ Staff should not accept parents as friends due to it being a breach of expected
  professional conduct unless they already know them in a personal capacity before their
  child starts at preschool. Staff should avoid personal communication, including on social
  networking sites, with the children and parents with whom they act in a professional
  capacity. If the staff names the preschool or workplace in any social media, they do so in
  a way that is not detrimental to the school or its families.
  ‚Ä¢ Staff observe confidentiality and refrain from discussing any issues relating to work. Staff
  should not share information they would not want children, parents or colleagues to
  view.
  ‚Ä¢ Staff and parents should report any concerns or breaches to the Director. Any member
  of staff, parent or volunteer found to be posting photos, remarks or comments that
  breach confidentiality, bring the preschool into disrepute or that are deemed to be of a
  detrimental nature to the preschool or other employees, or posting/publishing
  photographs of the setting, children or staff may face disciplinary action in line with the
  disciplinary procedures.
  ‚Ä¢ Any comment deemed to be inappropriate is to be reported to the Director or a staff
  member of the preschool and any action taken will be at their discretion.
 
  11
 Note: Precious People will use social media as a means of parent communication and for
 marketing purposes throughout the year
 
 Enrollment, Tuition, and Exit
 Admissions Process
 Children are eligible for admission at the age of 18 months. The admission process begins with a
 tour of the school. Children are enrolled on a first-come, first-serve basis, depending on
 availability in the most developmentally appropriate class. Children are placed on a waiting list if
 there is no availability in the most appropriate class. Once our classes fill, a wait list is created.
 To place your child‚Äôs name on the wait list, you must complete an Enrollment Application.
 
 Our classes are as follows:
 
  ‚Ä¢ Chipmunks: 18 months to 3 years old
  ‚Ä¢ Squirrels: 3 to 5 years old
  ‚Ä¢ Bunnies: Kindergartners
 
 Spaces are filled from the waiting list according to the following priority system:
 
  ‚Ä¢ Siblings of currently enrolled children
  ‚Ä¢ Previous Precious People families
  ‚Ä¢ General Public
 
 If a space becomes available, the child whose name is first on the wait list will be contacted. If
 that family wishes to enroll their child, we must receive the registration fee plus the child‚Äôs first
 week‚Äôs tuition within three business days. If we do not receive this deposit within three days,
 the spot will be offered to the next child on the waiting list. When space becomes available
 during the school year, it can be held for a maximum of thirty days. This allows the child to
 complete the month at their current school/childcare center.
 
 Enrollment Policy
 The school year begins during the first week of September. Registration for each school year
 starts in January of the preceding year, all fees and deposits are nonrefundable.
 
  1. For new students, after parents are notified of the admission date, you must complete
  the Precious People Enrollment Application and pay the non-refundable registration fee
  of $100 and first two weeks‚Äô tuition as a deposit are required to reserve your child‚Äôs
  space
 
  12
  Upon receipt of the Application and payment of registration fees, the parent receives
  the Parent‚Äôs Handbook, additional forms/policies, and health and immunization forms.
  2. For returning students in our Chipmunk and Squirrel classrooms who are attending
  summer camp, a completed Application is required with no annual registration fee.
  3. For all students not attending summer camp and those students attending the Bunny
  Kindergarten program, the first two weeks‚Äô tuition for September as a deposit is due
  when enrolling to hold your child‚Äôs space.
 
 On the first day a child attends school, the office must have in each child‚Äôs file:
 
  ‚Ä¢ A completed and signed Enrollment Application
  ‚Ä¢ Completed medical action plan (if applicable)
 
 Within 30 days of a child‚Äôs first date of attendance:
 
  ‚Ä¢ A health assessment by a licensed physician (Universal Health Form completed)
  ‚Ä¢ A record of immunization or a completed exemption form
 
 PLEASE NOTE: We are required to have each of these forms in our files to maintain our license
 to operate. State law requires us to exclude from school any student whose files are incomplete
 until we have received their missing paperwork. We appreciate your cooperation.
 
 Tuition
 There is a 10% discount for a sibling simultaneously attending Precious People. Tuition fees will
 remain constant from September through June. Tuition is due on the child‚Äôs first day of
 attendance of each month unless other arrangements are made.
 
 If your child is scheduled for 12:30 pickup but you would like your child to nap/rest at Precious
 People on occasion, it is a fee of $20 per child per day.
 
 Additionally,
 
  ‚Ä¢ All tuition and fees are nonrefundable
  ‚Ä¢ All tuition payments are due on the 1st of each month
  ‚Ä¢ The 2-week deposit paid at registration is applied to your first tuition payment unless
  you push back your start date and then another 2-week deposit is required for each
  newly defined start date
  ‚Ä¢ Payments are made for a place in Precious People‚Äôs programs and not for a period of
  attendance. The absence of a student does not materially decrease the expenses of the
  school. Hence, students are accepted for the entire school year.
  ‚Ä¢ You will be required to bring your account up to date to register for the following year or
  camp if tuition is owed at those times
 
  13
  ‚Ä¢ No bills or invoices are sent
  ‚Ä¢ No reduction or credit on the tuition will be granted if a student is expelled or is
  voluntarily withdrawn.
  ‚Ä¢ In the event of a mandated school closure we will provide a full day zoom schedule in
  place of in person classes until it is safe to return. Full tuition will be due to maintain our
  teachers' salaries, building and insurance.
 
 Late Payment Policy
 Monthly tuition is due by the 1st of every month. If tuition is two weeks late, a $50.00 late fee is
 added. If payment is three weeks late, an additional $75.00 late fee is added, and the child‚Äôs
 spot may be offered to a child on the waiting list.

 is playing, they are exploring and learning. KIDS ARE IMPORTANT AND HOGAN LANE

 REMOVEDion Statement
 At Evergreen Montessori, each child‚Äôs interests are respected, and we strive to assist in developing all aspects
 of the child‚Äôs being‚Ä¶social, emotional, spiritual, physical, and academic. We have a unique, low student to
 teacher ratio in a multi-age setting. Our peaceful and well-prepared classroom is designed to bring an
 element of choice into each child‚Äôs daily learning activities which empowers them to establish their
 independence. We do our best to provide a safe and nurturing learning environment where children can
 thrive and develop the necessary tools to become life-long learners. Evergreen Montessori aims to build
 relationships between children, families, educators, and the community, thereby establishing strong bonds
 that will lead to positive social communications and relations.
 
 Admission Procedures
  1. Ongoing Information ‚Äì All families interested in enrolling their child at Evergreen Montessori are encouraged to
  view our website and email for a copy of our handbook. If families are interested in pursuing a possible
  enrollment, we will record their contact information and request some basic information about their child.
 
  2. Re-enrollment - Upon returning from Winter Break, re-registration paperwork will be provided to families
  wishing to return for the following school year. All forms will need to be completely filled-out and returned with
  the necessary fees by the re-registration due date in late January.
 
  3. Informal Interviews ‚Äì Once open enrollment has begun in February, waitlisted families interested in enrolling
  their child at Evergreen Montessori will be contacted to schedule a tour and an informal interview with the
  Director and lead teacher. The director will explain the Montessori philosophy, daily routine, and answer any
  questions families may have, while the lead teacher will work one-on-one with the child to see how he/she
  responds to direction and the environment.
 
  4. Wait List ‚Äì Once the class space is filled for the following school year, families wishing for their child to attend
  will be added to our wait list. As space becomes available, these families will be contacted in the order in which
  they were placed on our wait list.
 
 Application Process:
 
  1. Applications from families wishing to continue at Evergreen Montessori are accepted first.
 
  2. Wait list family applications are accepted to enter school during the current or following year.
 
  3. New family applications are accepted to fill remaining available spaces or are placed on our wait list once all
  spaces are filled.
 
 * IMPORTANT REMINDER: Continuing families must re-register each year. Students are not automatically re-enrolled.
 
 Enrollment Packet
 You will receive a registration packet once your child has completed an informal child interview, and it is determined
 that our program is a good fit for your child. All completed forms must be turned into the office before your child may
 attend class. One exception is the Child Health Report, which is due within 30 days.
 
 Emergency Forms
 Current emergency forms providing accurate, up-to-date information are required by law. We should be informed of any
 changes in emergency information at any given time. New emergency forms are required each new school year.
 Additionally, these forms will need to be updated and re-signed for any changes or lack thereof during Parent
 Conferences at the beginning of November and again at the beginning of May.
 Orientation Meeting
 All families will be required to have a parent/guardian of the child enrolled at Evergreen Montessori attend our Parent
 Orientation Meeting at the end of August, prior to the first day of school. Families that have a child starting one of our
 programs in the middle of the year will be asked to attend the Parent Orientation Meeting in August as well.
 
 Special Needs Children
 Special needs children are admitted on a case-by-case basis.
 
 Non-Discrimination Policy
 Evergreen Montessori, LLC admits students of any race, color, religious creed, disability, ancestry, national origin
 (including limited English proficiency), or sex to all the rights, privileges, programs, and activities generally accorded or
 made available to students at the school. It does not discriminate based on race, color, national and ethnic origin, sex,
 political beliefs, marital status, disability, or special needs in administration of its educational policies, admission policies,
 and other school administered programs.
 
 Program services shall be made accessible to eligible persons with disabilities through the most practical and
 economically feasible methods available. These methods include, but are not limited to, equipment redesign, the
 provision of aides, and the use of alternative service delivery locations. Structural modifications shall be considered only
 as a last resort among available methods.
 
 Developmental Needs and Special Services
 At Evergreen Montessori, our philosophy focuses on child development through a constructive means. The teacher may
 identify behavioral or developmental needs in young children that parents may or may not recognize. Every effort will
 be made to involve the parents/guardians in the process of identifying any needs that may arise and working towards
 possible solutions. In these instances, the teacher may recommend professional screening in order to obtain the
 necessary services to help create a successful learning experience for your child.
 
 Termination
 The child's developmental needs come first at Evergreen Montessori. Therefore, if the teacher has a concern that these
 needs are not being appropriately met in our school, or if the teacher believes that our school program cannot meet the
 needs of the parent/guardian, we will work together to identify the problem and seek solutions.
 
 However, if reasonable and appropriate interventions have been attempted and are not resulting in necessary change,
 then Evergreen Montessori may determine that our school is not in the best interest of the child or the parent/guardian.
 In this case, the directress reserves the right to request that the child be withdrawn from the program. Assistance will
 be provided to the family, as best as possible, in finding a program that will meet their child's needs. Withdrawal
 procedures will be implemented in the time frame that Evergreen Montessori believes is appropriate.
 
 IMPORTANT NOTICE: Evergreen Montessori reserves the right to suspend services to any family due to behavioral
 problems in dealing with a child or parents.
 
 Confidentiality
 It is Evergreen Montessori‚Äôs policy that any information regarding the child, the child's family, or other matters discussed
 with the Directress will be held in the strictest confidence.
 
 Licensing Regulations
 Evergreen Montessori is licensed by the Pennsylvania Department of Education and the Pennsylvania Department of
 Human Services, Office of Child Development and Early Learning. You may access the Child Care Center regulations
 online at:
 http://www.pacodeandbulletin.gov/Display/pacode?file=/secure/pacode/data/055/chapter3270/chap3270toc.html&d=

 Evergreen Montessori follows the Carlynton School District schedule for school closings or delays for bad weather.
 Parents should watch the local television stations for the Carlynton Schools listing. We also recommend you register for

 Tuition
 Tuition Computation/Fees
 There is a $50.00 non-refundable registration fee, a $100.00 non-refundable tuition deposit which is applied to the
 tuition total, and a $250 non-refundable activity and materials fee that is due upon registration. Tuition is determined
 on a yearly basis and is divided by ten with monthly installments being paid from September through June. Our
 operating budget includes periodic holidays, staff in-service days, and anticipated child absences. Tuition is non-
 adjustable. Credits or rebates cannot be given, as Evergreen Montessori has limited enrollment and fixed costs.
 Evergreen Montessori does not send out monthly bills. Therefore, it is the parent(s)/guardian(s) responsibility to make
 sure tuition payments are made NO LATER than the 3rd of each month unless otherwise specified on the Enrollment
 Form.
 
 Second Child Family Discount
 Families that enroll a second child will receive a 10% discount on the second child‚Äôs tuition, which will be deducted from
 their monthly payment.
 
 Late Fees
 A late charge of $15.00 is due if your monthly payment is not received by the 5th of each month. If a payment is not
 received by the 15th of the month, the child may not return to school until the tuition balance is paid in full. A $35.00
 fee will be charged to your account for each check labeled with insufficient funds.

 Notification of Withdrawal
 All cases involving withdraw shall be notified to the Directress in writing. It is understood that...
 
  ‚Ä¢ Students who enroll and withdraw within less than one month prior to August 26, 2025 shall be entitled to a

 It is further understood that the Director of the school reserves the right to suspend or dismiss a student for justifiable
 cause, including unpaid tuition.
 Before Care
 Before Care will start at 8:00am, Monday through Friday. There are two options from which to choose. The first option
 is to utilize the services as needed. The cost will be evaluated on a daily basis at a rate of $5.00 per day. The second
 option will be to utilize the services full-time.
 
 If you anticipate the need for before care services at some point during the school year, then we ask you to choose
 option one and complete the registration form. The use of the flexible program will be billed at the beginning of the
 subsequent month.
 
 If you choose to enroll your child in the full-time before care, payment is due at the beginning of each month along with
 tuition. Payment is due NO LATER than the 3rd of each month unless otherwise specified. The cost for this program is
 divided over the course of nine months; therefore, there is no pro-rating of fees based on attendance or holidays. If
 your monthly payment is not received on time, a $15.00 late charge will be assessed. A $35.00 fee will be charged to
 your account for each returned check.
 
 Before Care will not be available if there are any issues with the physical location, the school is closed due to weather, or
 if an emergency situation were to arise. Please note: On days when we operate on a two-hour delay, Before Care will
 not be available.

 Extended Day
 Extended Day will be offered Monday through Friday from your child‚Äôs dismissal time until 4:00pm. There are
 two options to choose from when enrolling your child in our Extended Day program. The first option is to

 If your child is in the 3 year old program, Extended Day services need to be approved by the director in order to

 If you choose to enroll your child in the full-time Extended Day program, payment is due each month starting

 If you choose to enroll your child in the flexible program, your cost will be billed monthly based on your usage
 of the program. Therefore, shortly following month‚Äôs end, you will receive a statement and your payment will

 If you are not present at pick up within 5 minutes of your child‚Äôs dismissal time, there will be a late pickup

 A late charge of $15.00 is due if your monthly payment is not received on time. A $35.00 fee will be charged to

 Extended Day will not be available if there are any issues with the physical location, the school is closed due to
