 Illness Policy
 
 IMPORTANT NOTICE: In an effort to mitigate the spread of illness, we ask that parents agree to be diligent and
 forthcoming with information so that we may prioritize the health and safety of all children and staff.
 
 *Evergreen Montessori reserves the right to make changes based upon CDC recommendations. Parents/guardians will
 be notified in writing immediately if any changes occur to this document.
 
 In order to prevent the spread of germs and provide comfort, a child showing signs of illness may not attend school.
 Therefore, your child must remain home, or will be sent home, for any one of the following conditions.
  ‚Ä¢ Fever - A temperature of 100 degrees. Child's temperature must be normal for 24 hours before returning to
  school.
  ‚Ä¢ Diarrhea - Child must be symptom free for a full 24 hours before returning to school.
  ‚Ä¢ Vomiting - Child must be symptom free for 24 hours before returning to school.
  ‚Ä¢ Severe upper respiratory illness - including congestion, constant uncontrolled nasal discharge, mucus in the
  eyes, colored mucus in the nose, severe uncontrolled productive cough (raising phlegm).
  ‚Ä¢ Any lesion, wound, or skin rash with bleeding or oozing of clear fluid or pus - A child may be returned when:
  (1.) a health care provider signs a note stating that the condition is not contagious, and
  (2.) the area can be covered by a bandage without any drainage through the bandage.
  ‚Ä¢ Mouth sores with drooling
  ‚Ä¢ Severe injury
  ‚Ä¢ Any condition which appears to need medical attention, which keeps a child from participating comfortably in
  usual activities, or which requires one-on-one care.
 
  IMPORTANT NOTICE: Please report the following to Evergreen Montessori so that we may inform the parents of
  the other children of a possible outbreak.
 
  ‚Ä¢ Skin infections or rashes ‚Äì these may include but are not limited to ringworm, impetigo, measles, chicken pox,
  herpes, etc.
  ‚Ä¢ Communicable diseases ‚Äì these may include but are not limited to measles, tuberculosis, whooping cough, etc.
  which are reportable to the Department of Public Health
  ‚Ä¢ Head Lice, Scabies or other infestations
  ‚Ä¢ Conjunctivitis ("pink eye") - with white or yellow discharge.
 
 The final decision as to whether a child may attend school or should to be excluded from an event is made by the
 Director(s). We may request that a doctor's release be obtained before the child returns to school.
 
 Medication
 Prescription or over the counter medication can only be administered when accompanied by a completed Medication
 Log, as stated in 55 Pa. Code 3270.133; 3280.133; and 3290.133, providing parent permission to a caretaker to
 administer the medication. A new medication log must be filled out, signed and dated for each separate medication or a
 new time period.
 
  ‚Ä¢ Prescription medication - If medicine is a "prescribed" medication from a doctor, it must be in the prescription
  bottle and labeled with the child's name, the time to be administered, and the dosage amount. Medication
  labeled for someone else cannot be given to your child.
  ‚Ä¢ Over the counter medication - If medication is an over-the-counter medication, then clear directions must be
  printed on the label appropriate to the age of the child.
 Practices, Policies, and Procedures related to illnesses
 
 If your child becomes sick at school:
 
 All students will be observed throughout the day. If your child exhibits or communicates symptoms or conditions, then
 we will follow the protocol listed below:
 
  1. Parents/guardians will be contacted immediately.
  2. Your child will be made comfortable in a designated area where they can be appropriately separated from all
  other students and asked to put a mask on. A staff member will have eye contact and direct supervision of your
  child until they are picked up.
  3. CDC guidelines for cleaning and disinfecting the area where the child was working will be followed.
  4. Staff will clean and disinfect all surfaces in the area where the child was separated and resting once the sick child
  has gone home.
 
 Isolation
 
 Remain home while a fever and symptoms persist.
 
 Ending Isolation
 
  1. You can go back to your normal activities when, for at least 24 hours, both are true:
  a. Your symptoms are getting better overall, and
  b. You have not had a fever (and are not using fever-reducing medication).
  2. When you go back to your normal activities, take added precaution over the next 5 days, such as taking
  additional steps for cleaner air, hygiene, masks, physical distancing, and/or testing when you will be
  around other people indoors. This is especially important to protect people with factors that increase their risk
  of severe illness from respiratory viruses.
 
 Wearing a Mask
 
 Your child may be asked to wear a mask if they are exhibiting symptoms such as persistent coughing, sneezing,
 or runny nose that they are having a difficult time managing.
 
 If an illness is confirmed in a child or staff member:
 
  1. The areas used by the child or staff member will be closed off.
  2. Outside doors and windows will be opened to increase air circulation in the areas.
  3. All areas used by the person, such as offices, bathrooms, and common areas will be cleaned and disinfected.
  4. The directress will inform parents/guardians of enrolled children when there is a suspected outbreak of a
  communicable disease or an outbreak of an unusual illness that represents a public emergency according to the
  Department of Health as per 55 Pa. Code 3270.136(b), 3280.136 (b), and 3290.136 (b).
 
 Pennsylvania Office of Child Development and Early Learning, Bureau of Early Learning Policy and Professional
 Development and Bureau of Certification. (2021 June 28). Best Practices for Child Care Facilities Operating During the
 Novel Coronavirus.
 Discipline
 Positive Discipline Guidelines
 
 Evergreen Montessori is committed to providing a supportive and nurturing learning environment where young children
 can grow and achieve their maximum potential. We appreciate each child‚Äôs unique qualities and characteristics, and we
 follow each child's individual chronological development.
 
 We believe "discipline" is a teaching and learning experience, not a punishment. As situations for social and behavioral
 growth occur, the teacher will facilitate resolution and encourage problem-solving on the part of the children involved.
 ‚ÄúDoing the right thing‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Golden Rule: Treat others the way you would want them to treat you‚Äù are our guiding
 principles here at Evergreen Montessori.
 
 The following guidelines are used when teaching children to take responsibility for their actions:
 
  1. Set realistic expectations for young children's behavior.
  2. Create a prepared environment that contributes to appropriate behavior.
  3. Model and encourage positive communication techniques.
  4. Assist children in exploring alternatives for constructive problem-solving.
  5. Teach children to use their words appropriately and take responsibility for the role they assumed in the situation.
  6. Use natural and logical consequences.
 Preschool Daily Schedule
 Children like predictable routines, so we follow the same schedule every day. The times are slightly flexible to
 accommodate the activities of the day.

 Circle Time
 All children will sit quietly in a circle with the teacher. We begin by reviewing the calendar (the season, weather for the
 day, and date). Music follows our calendar time as we sing songs and engage in finger plays and movement activities.
 Periodically, we bring out beanbags and simple instruments (rhythm sticks, triangles, drums, etc.) to accompany the
 songs. Our songs assist in teaching concepts such as days of the week, months of the year, letter sounds, animal sounds,
 sharing, feelings, colors and shapes, rhythms, or any other conceptual theme we may be integrating into our curriculum
 that week. Circle time ends with a story or reading several poems, discussing the content, and asking comprehension
 questions.
 
 Character Building:
 Two main resources that Evergreen Montessori incorporates into our daily character-building program are: ‚ÄúHonoring
 the Light of the Child‚Äù and ‚ÄúNurturing the Spirit‚Äù.
 
 Our small group readings, discussions, songs, and activities are primarily concerned with developing each child‚Äôs social-
 emotional skills and nurturing their inner spirit. A different character-building theme will be addressed each month
 throughout the school year. Each week, the teacher will lead her group through one of many structured activities
 focused on a particular theme. These activities are designed to provide children with the tools necessary for living a
 balanced and healthy life. Monthly themes include topics such as: ‚ÄúHonoring the Light Within‚Äù, cooperation, self-
 confidence, conflict resolution skills, empathy, gentleness, respect, self-control, freedom, honesty, humility, love, peace,
 responsibility, simplicity, tolerance, and unity.
 
 Gross Motor Development
 Indoor/outdoor play is another important time in each child's day. During this time, they get to develop their strength,
 coordination, and body awareness by engaging in a variety of activities, which includes but is not limited to throwing and
 catching, running, jumping, crawling, hula hooping, playing hopscotch, participating in imaginary play and organized
 sports. Additionally, they can socialize with their peers and increase their communication skills.
 Snack Time and Lunch
 Evergreen Montessori is focused on assisting in the development of the whole child which means setting the stage for
 establishing healthy habits socially, emotionally, physically, spiritually, and academically. By teaching children healthy
 eating habits from an early age, we may have a positive impact on their physical growth and development. This should
 help decrease the risk of future health problems that are directly related.
 
 Snack
 At Snack Time, we ask that you pack your child fruits, vegetables, healthy snacks, and water. We encourage the
 avoidance of foods high in sugar and fat. We ask each parent to provide their child with a daily snack. Each day should
 consist of two different snack options, one prepared snack and one that requires some basic food preparation that the
 child can engage in themself. Snack options are listed below.
 
 Children may choose to have their snack at any point during Montessori time when they are hungry. A snack table will
 be set up for the children so they may independently prepare their plate and eat their snack.
 
 Prepared Snack Ideas Snack Preparation Ideas
  Fruit snacks Grapes to pick off a bunch
  Sliced apples Bread and butter to spread on
  Scooby snacks Waffles with syrup or powdered
  Pretzels sugar to drizzle on top
  Yogurt Mini bagels with cream cheese or butter to Granola bars
  spread on top
  Cheese sticks Veggies with ranch to dip in
  Banana or Zucchini bread Bananas to peel and slice
  Dried fruit Crackers and cheese to slice on top
  Yogurt covered raisins Healthy cereal with milk
 
 Weekly Snack Menus
 Sample #1 Sample #2 Sample #3
  Bunch of grapes Veggies and dip 3- 4 Bananas
  Box of fruit snacks

  Moose Alley Daycare Parent Informational Packet
 Thank you for your interest in Moose Alley Daycare. This packet contains some helpful
 information about our daycare center. Upon enrollment, a parent handbook will be provided to
 you with our full policy and procedures.
 A Little About Moose Alley Daycare
 Located at 99 Bailey Hill Rd in Poland, Moose Alley Daycare LLC was first established in June
 of 2022 as the daycare and property was purchased by new owners Ashlie & Andrew Gagnon.
 Ashlie & Andrew, along with our Director Renee Lancaster and our team of dedicated staff,
 worked to ensure that the need for high quality childcare was met in our small town. We are a
 family owned and run business. We are happy to serve our community and our area children and
 look forward to working with you to provide a secure foundation for your child to ensure
 successful growth and learning. We are licensed to care for children up to 31 children, ages 6
 weeks to 12 years old. We are open from 7am-5pm Monday to Friday. We believe that children
 being outside and enjoying nature is beneficial in an abundance of ways. We strive to incorporate
 many outdoor activities into our curriculum.
 Our REMOVEDion Statement
 Nurturing your child is the most important part of the Moose Alley Daycare program. We will
 provide encouragement, and enriching experiences. Nurturing your child means showing
 support, help, concern, and understanding-all things that are part of the special closeness between
 a caregiver and your child. We believe that play is a vital part of a child‚Äôs development. Our
 daycare program encourages creative play. There are opportunities for independent play and
 group play, as well as a mixture of both structured and unstructured time, both inside and
 outside. We provide the ability to develop fine motor and gross motor skills and encourage
 different activities to promote both skill sets.
 At Moose Alley Daycare children learn how to behave appropriately with other children. They
 learn to socialize and how to process and handle their emotions. Effective guidance helps
 children to get along with others and teaches children how to deal with their own feelings in
 acceptable, appropriate ways. This helps promote security and a positive self-concept. Moose
 Alley Daycare provides your child with a relaxed, safe atmosphere in which to develop, learn,
 and grow. We challenge each child to grow and develop at their own pace by exposing them to
 concepts that help them to understand their world. We believe that children learn through a
 variety of experiences. Some of these activities should be consistent in their day, and some
 should be different for variety and interest. We believe that the best childcare depends on
 consistent caregiving in a home-like atmosphere. Children grow and learn best in a safe
 environment that provides opportunities to explore, create and communicate with other children
 and adults. These groups function independently but cooperatively, following routines
 appropriate to individual needs. The program is designed to be inclusive of all children,
 including those with identified disabilities, special learning and developmental needs.
 Non-Discrimination Policy
 It is the policy of Moose Alley Daycare not to discriminate based on race, color, religion (creed),
 gender, gender expression, age, national origin (ancestry), disability, marital status, or sexual
 orientation, on any of its activities or operations. We are committed to providing an inclusive and
 welcoming environment for all members of our staff, children and families we serve, and
 volunteers. We follow all laws set forth by the ADA and are a fully accessible daycare center.
 Enrollment Procedures
 Before your child is enrolled, you will be asked to tour the facility, and stay for a period, once or
 twice, depending on how your child reacts to their new environment. Once your child is enrolled,
 we ask that you complete the enrollment packet and return all the paperwork, including
 up-to-date immunization records, by the first day of attendance. Each of these forms is required
 by the State of Maine for licensing standards. Please notify the program of any changes to your
 child‚Äôs information as soon as possible.
 We require a non-refundable deposit (equal to one week's payment) in order to hold your child's
 spot. Your child will not be enrolled, and the spot will not be considered filled until deposit is
 received. Payment will be applied he deposit to your child‚Äôs first week of care when they attend.
 If you are on a waitlist, you do not need to pay a deposit until the spot is offered to you. Upon the
 offer, you would then need to pay the deposit to secure the spot.
 Licensing requires that immunization records be kept on file and up to date for all children
 enrolled.
 **Anytime your child goes to the doctor‚Äôs office and has shots, please bring an updated
 immunization record to add to your child‚Äôs file or have them emailed/faxed to us.**
 For a list of mandatory vaccines for your child to attend daycare please visit:
 https://www.maine.gov/dhhs/mecdc/infectious-disease/immunization/documents/Daycare-Immu
 nization-standards-revised.pdf
 We ask that each child bring:
 - Their immunization records. These can also be faxed to us directly from the physician‚Äôs office
 to 207-998-2109 or emailed to moosealleydaycare@gmail.com We must have immunization
 records within 30 days of enrollment.
 - All completed enrollment packed paperwork.
 - 2 full sets of extra clothes (Weather appropriate and including socks!)
 -diapers/wipes if your child is not toilet trained
 -bottles/formula/breastmilk/jarred baby food if appropriate for your child.
 -LUNCH DAILY (we provide morning and afternoon snack and drink)
 -Water bottle to keep at daycare(if over 1) if under 1, a sippy cup is great! This will be labeled
 and only used by your child.
 -children over 18 months-blanket for rest time/small pillow, small stuffy or comfort item. Rest
 time items will be sent home at the end of each week and should be returned the following week
 washed.
  Classrooms
 Infant Classroom
 Our infant classroom schedule is based on each individual infant's needs, abilities, and emotions.
 We provide a creative and stimulating environment that promotes visual, language, gross motor,
 and small motor experiences to enhance learning through each infant's own natural curiosity. At
 each stage of development, our experienced infant teacher will guide your child, and provide
 loving care along the way. Our teacher provides parents with a daily report on each infant's
 activities throughout the day(bottles, diaper changes, feedings etc).
 Toddler Classroom
 The toddler classroom is designed to provide stimulating experiences where toddlers can learn
 through their own inquisitiveness, and emphasizes building self-confidence, learning to navigate
 emotions, building friendships, and fostering the natural curiosity that toddlers have. Our daily
 lesson plans promote art/sensory experiences, music, gross motor, fine motor, and science skills.
 We have indoor play and outdoor play daily. Our teacher guides and gently directs our toddlers to
 explore their surroundings through positive and comforting interactions, activities, and fun
 playtime.
 Preschool Classroom
 Our preschool program provides children with plenty of opportunities for expanding their social
 skills, vocabulary, team building, caring, all while learning their academics in a fun and exciting
 manner! They will spend their day actively learning in the creative arts area, sensory table,
 reading corner, using manipulative in creative building, pretend play in kitchens and dress-up
 costumes, and so much more! Our preschool daily schedule includes circle time, center play,
 language arts, math, science, and sensory exploration along with outdoor play. Children in this
 classroom follow a predictable routine and participate in community jobs in their classroom.
 School Age Classroom
 The school age program is for children who attend school full time (kindergarten through
 elementary grades). Our school age program gives children a safe and fun space to play and learn
 before and after school. During school vacations students participate in fun activities that help to
 support both their social and academic growth.
 
 Rates
 All our slots are full-time spaces, unless otherwise agreed upon with the Owner and Director.
 Rates are subject to change with written advanced notice of policy.
 
 Infant (6 weeks-1 year) $ 230/week
 Toddler (1year-3 year) $205/week
 Preschool (3 year-5 (not in K) $190/week
 School Age (5(in K)-12 years) $100/week before/after care only. School closure and vacation
 days rate changes. See Director for school age availability.
 Moose Alley Daycare Sample Schedule
 7:00am-8:00am-arrival times/wash hands upon arrival/free play
 8:15-potty/diapers/wash hands. AM Snack
 8:45-Circle Time/Weather/Phonics
 9:00-small group centers/art/sensory/math/science
 9:45-potty/diapers/wash hands. Outdoor play
 11:00-Lunch (hand washing before meal)
 12:00-potty/diapers/wash hands. Quiet time
 2:00-potty/diapers/wash hands/free choice
 2:45-wash hands. PM Snack
 3:15-Outdoor play (weather permitting) and pick up
 5:00-Daycare closes
 *Schedules vary by classroom and are dependent on age and developmental needs of children*

 small, nurturing center with three classrooms dedicated to providing exceptional
 care for children from 6 weeks to 3.5 years old.
 
 At the heart of our philosophy is building wonderful, lasting connections with
 our children and their families. We believe strong relationships are the
 foundation for a happy and secure learning environment. To keep you involved and

 daily reports, and direct messaging.

  Longs Peak Learning Center
  RESERVATION FORM
 
 Our reservation form is to help you get your child into your first choice for child care. We thank you for choosing to add your child
 to Longs Peak Learning Center's reservation list. In order to secure your child‚Äôs spot on the list, we ask that you return this
 completed reservation form and deposit to the Director. Checks can be made payable to Longs Peak Learning Center.
 
  TERMS, CONDITIONS, & DISCLOSURES
  o Enrollment opportunities depend on available spaces in the school as well as your child‚Äôs birth date and age. There is no
  guarantee that an opening will be available on your preferred start date and you may be offered a different schedule/start date.
 
  o A child on the reservation list will be placed in the order that it‚Äôs received. Placing a child‚Äôs name on the reservation list and
  placing a deposit does not guarantee enrollment.
 
  o Deposit amounts vary depending on what care is desired. 100% of your deposit will go towards the first month‚Äôs tuition.
  This deposit is non-refundable.
 
  o LPLC will contact you when a spot is available. If we do not hear back from you after 3 days or you have not made a decision
  within those 3 days, we will move on to the next family. If you decline an offered spot 3 consecutive times, the child‚Äôs name
  will be removed and forfit your deposit.
 
  o Once the space is accepted, there needs to be an exact start date in place.
 
  o You are required to begin paying for the space on the day it is available. Space will not be held without payment of monthly
  tuition.
 
  o Currently enrolled children will receive priority for transitioning into an older classroom. Siblings of currently enrolled children
  will also receive priority.
 
  o There is very limited part time availability. Currently enrolled families who are part time that desire to go full time will be given
  first priority over full time applicants on the waiting list.
 
  o Part time enrollees are considered paired; meaning that they are occupying only one space e.g. MWF & TTh. If you need part
  time and only a full time spot is available, you could take the full time spot at full tuition and have freedom to pick and choose
  your days of the week. No minimum attendance required.
 
  o Full time enrollment always has priority over part time. LPLC has the right to end care for part time families, with a 30 day
  notice, if they are not part of a complete part time pair.
 
  o We may check in with families on the wait list from time to time to see if any of your needs have changed since your initial
  application.
 
  o Please let us know as soon as possible if you find alternate care and would like to cancel your reservation.
 
  o Your tuition is based on current rates when your child begins care.

  Longs Peak Learning Center
  PARENT HANDBOOK
 
  ABOUT US
  We are locally owned and operated, child care center that is driven and inspired by our vision to provide the very best in
  infant care and early childhood education. We‚Äôve carefully crafted every aspect of our business with the children, parents,
  and teachers at the forefront. That means we‚Äôre breaking the mold and delivering an innovative, chic, and modernized
  brand of child care.
  MISSION STATEMENT
  We want to partner with you to ensure the children get the most out of their school experience. By introducing children to
  play, art, and academics with an actively involved teacher to help ensure safe and high quality care. We recognize that
  every child learns and develops at their own pace, so our curriculum can be just as flexible to the child's level of interest
  helping create both equality and individualism.
  PHILOSOPHY (a)
  At LPLC we will focus on a developmental based program that is theTraditional Learning Style; where physical, cognitive,
  social and emotional aspects of learning will be encouraged. We will incorporate early beginnings of STEM which stands
  for science, technology, engineering and mathematics. With technology advancing and always changing in the works
  around us we want to introduce this in the early years to children. Learning these techniques through both hands-on and
  teacher led activities can help assure future success.
  We want our families and staff to be happy. We encourage strong teacher-parent relationships and child/teacher
  relationships in order to maintain a successful journey in their education. We will never stop learning, listening and
  imagining.
  CENTER INFORMATION
 
  ADMINISTRATION Christy Creek
  director@lplc.co
  Executive Director: Office ‚Äì (303) 678-5555
  Cell ‚Äì (720) 530-8653
 
  Director: Courtney Hood
  courtneyhood@lplc.co
  Office - (303) 678-5555
 
  HOURS OF OPERATION (c)
  Longs Peak Learning Center operates Monday through Friday from 7:00am to 5:00pm and will be closed
  for the following 2025 holiday‚Äôs and staff days.
  January 1st New Years Day
  January 20th Martin Luther King Jr Day
  February 17th President'd Day/ Staff Day
  April 18th Staff Day
  May 26th Memorial Day
  July 4th Independance Day
  August 8th Staff Day
  September 1st Labor Day
  October 10th Staff Day
  November 27th Thanksgiving Day
  November 28th Day after Thanksgiving
  December 25th Christmas Day
  December 26th Day after Christmas
 LPLC PARENT HANDBOOK ‚Äì Rev 1/2025 - ¬©2017 Longs Peak Learning Center, Co. All Rights Reserved Page 2/19
 HOLIDAYS
 LPLC is closed annually in observance of the following holidays:
 New Year‚Äôs Day
 Martin Luther King Day
 Presidents‚Äô Day
 Memorial Day
 Independence Day
 Labor Day
 Thanksgiving Day
 Christmas Day
 
 If the holiday falls on a weekend day, LPLC will close during the week. For example, if New Year‚Äôs Day falls on a
 Saturday, LPLC may close on Friday or Monday. Families will be given at least 2 weeks‚Äô notice in the event of
 additional closings. Reminders will be sent through the Brightwheel application.
 
 AGES OF CHILDREN ACCEPTED (b)
 Longs Peak Learning Center provides infant and toddler care. For children beginning at 6 weeks old up to 36 months of
 age.
 
 PROGRAMS
 Longs Peak Learning Center is a newer center. We are center with three classrooms.
 
 WEATHER RELATED CLOSINGS
 LPLC will remain open during most severe weather. The Director and/or Assistant Director will monitor the weather and
 local news to determine when it is appropriate to close the center early or cancel care for the following day.
 In the event that LPLC closes early or cancels care for the following day, parents will be contacted and informed of the
 situation. Children should be picked up in a reasonable amount of time to ensure all parents, children, and staff can travel
 safely home.
 
 INCLEMENT AND EXCESSIVELY HOT WEATHER (d)
 Infants: We will have outdoor play for infants at least 3 times per week, however we ensure the safety of the children at all
 times. We will not have outdoor playtime during inclement and excessively hot weather but will have indoor large gross
 motor activities.
  ‚Ä¢ Outdoor
  If temperature is above 30¬∞F and lower than 95¬∞F, the infants will make it outside three times a week, if not more.
 Infants will be in the buggy for a walk around on the center property or in their playground area in which they are able to
 crawl, walk, roll, climb, explore and develop gross motor skills with the peek-a-boo caterpillar and/or the tot tree. They will
 also explore the sandbox if old enough, as well as any additional appropriate toys that may be brought outside.
  ‚Ä¢ Indoor
  If the temperature outside is below 30¬∞F or above 95¬∞F, there will be limited and/or no outside time and infants will
 stay indoors. Infants will have their designated classroom to explore and develop their fine and gross motor skills, such as,
 moving arms and legs around, rolling over, crawling, pulling up, cruising on furniture, walking with assistance, painting,
 throwing balls, building with blocks, and using a climbing pad. If an infant is emerging at a skill or a developmental
 milestone, the teacher will be there to encourage and support the child.
 Toddlers: We will have outdoor play for toddlers daily, however we ensure the safety of the children at all times. We will
 not have outdoor playtime during inclement and excessively hot weather but will have indoor large gross motor activities.
  ‚Ä¢ Outdoor
  Every day the temperature is above 30¬∞F and lower than 95¬∞F, toddlers will be outside for at least 60 minutes.
 Toddlers will have their playground equipment to play on and around, a sandbox for sensory exploration, as well as
 learning new motor skills of scooping and dumping and any additional appropriate toys to explore. In the playground area,
 toddlers can run or have a race, explore and learn skipping, jumping, hopping, marching, dance, imagine they are animals
 like a large bird flying or a big brown bear crawling around, ride bikes, throw balls or engage in any activity the teacher
 may introduce.
  ‚Ä¢ Indoor
  If the temperature outside is below 30¬∞F or above 95¬∞F, there will be limited and/or no outside time. Toddlers will have
 their designated classroom to explore and develop their fine and gross motor skills, such as, climbing, crawling over pillows
 or other items, jumping, building blocks, stepping up and down stairs, dancing, yoga or even an art project with fun utensils.
 
 LPLC PARENT HANDBOOK ‚Äì Rev 1/2025 - ¬©2017 Longs Peak Learning Center, Co. All Rights Reserved Page 3/19
  UPDATING ENROLLMENT RECORDS (e)
  Each fall, LPLC completes an audit of enrollment records. At the conclusion of this audit, families will be notified if
  anything needs to be updated. Some forms must be updated annually, including the Emergency Contact and Authorization
  for Emergency Medical Care forms.
 
  Other records must be updated throughout the year, such as physicals and immunization records. When visiting your
  child‚Äôs physician for a ‚Äúwell-child‚Äù appointment, please request to have the doctor fill out a LPLC General Health Appraisal
  Form for your child‚Äôs physical and a copy of their most recent immunization record. You may bring these items in yourself,
  or have your physician email them to us at director@lplc.co
  Registration forms and deposits must be completed for all children before enrollment. The child‚Äôs General Health Appraisal
  Form and the immunization record is due at the time of enrollment. The first month‚Äôs tuition is due on your child‚Äôs first
  day of enrollment.
 
  ITEMIZED FEE SCHEDULE (f)
  Longs Peak Learning Center has a monthly tuition. Tuition fees are not subject to proration for holidays, weather
  related closures, emergency closures, or illness. I agree to pay the full tuition fee even if my child is absent for
  one or more days.
  There is a mandatory 30 day notice if you are disenrolling your child from Longs Peak Learning Center.
 
  A late pick-up fee of $2 for every additional minute after 5:00pm will be charged when a child is left beyond Longs
  Peak Learning Center‚Äôs operating hours. The late pick-up fee does not constitute an agreement to provide afterhours
  care.
  All tuition is due in advance of services rendered and are due on the first business day of the month. If tuition is not paid in
  full within five (5) days of the due date, you may be subject to a late fee of $50.00. Accounts two (2) weeks in arrears may
  result in immediate termination of service and all unpaid balances may be referred to a collection agency. If sent to
  collections, I will be responsible for the balance of my account and any reasonable collection and attorney fees or costs
  associated with the collection of the account.
  Returned checks are subject to a $20 nonsufficient funds fee and are subject to collection costs in the amount of $20 or
  20% of the check amount, whichever is greater.
 
  CONFIDENTIALITY
  Confidentiality is a top priority for LPLC. Personal information of families and staff will not be shared for any reason
  without prior written consent of the individual. When discussing a child‚Äôs activities and friends in the classroom, only first
  names will be used. In situations regarding behavior problems and/or Incident Reports, names of children involved will not
  be given to families.
 
  LICENSING
  LPLC is a program licensed by the Colorado Department of Human Services. A copy of the licensing rules are available
  for review in the office and on the web coloradoofficeofearlychildhood.com
  ADMISSIONS
  ‚Ä¢ Enrollment opportunities depend on available spaces in the school as well as your child‚Äôs birth date and age. There is no
  guarantee that an opening will be available on your preferred start date and you may be offered a different schedule/start date.
  ‚Ä¢ A child on the reservation list will be placed in the order that it‚Äôs received. Placing a child‚Äôs name on the reservation list and
  placing a deposit does not guarantee enrollment.
  ‚Ä¢ Deposit amounts vary depending on what care is desired. Your deposit will go towards the first month‚Äôs tuition.
  ‚Ä¢ The deposit is non-refunable.
  ‚Ä¢ LPLC will contact you when a spot is available. If we do not hear back from you after 3 days or you have not made a decision
  within those 3 days, we will move on to the next family. If you decline an offered spot 3 consecutive times, the child‚Äôs name will
  be removed and forit your deposit.
  ‚Ä¢ Once the space is accepted, there needs to be an exact start date in place.
  ‚Ä¢ You are required to begin paying for the space on the day it is available. Space will not be held without payment of monthly tuition.
  ‚Ä¢ Currently enrolled children will receive priority for transitioning into an older classroom. Siblings of currently enrolled children will also
  receive priority.
  ‚Ä¢ There is very limited part time availability. Currently enrolled families who are part time that desire to go full time will be given
  first priority over full time applicants on the waiting list.
  ‚Ä¢ Part time enrollees are considered paired; meaning that they are occupying only one space ex: MWF & TTh. If you need
  part time and only a full time spot is available, you could take the full time spot at full tuition and have freedom to pick and
  choose your days of the week. No minimum attendance required.
  ‚Ä¢ Full time enrollment always has priority over part time. LPLC has the right to end care for part time families, with a 30 day notice, if they
  are not part of a complete part time pair.
 LPLC PARENT HANDBOOK ‚Äì Rev 1/2025 - ¬©2017 Longs Peak Learning Center, Co. All Rights Reserved Page 4/19
  ‚Ä¢ Your tuition is based on current rates when your child begins care.
 
  ASSESSMENTS
 PARENT-TEACHER CONFERENCES (v)
 Parent-teacher conferences will be held at least twice per year with the child‚Äôs primary teacher. The goal of the parent-
 teacher conference is to gain insight into your child‚Äôs development both in the center setting as well as the home setting.
 During conferences, your child‚Äôs development and any goals you may have for your child will be discussed as well as any
 questions or concerns that you may have. Parents are encouraged to request conferences whenever they feel it
 necessary.
 
 ASSESSMENT PORTFOLIOS
 A permanent assessment portfolio will be kept for each child. These portfolios will not be released to anyone outside
 Longs Peak Learning Center without written permission from the parent/guardian. Assessment portfolios will contain a
 variety of items, including photographs, examples of artwork, assessment profiles, and parent-teacher conference forms.
 Portfolios may be periodically taken home by families but should be returned promptly. When a child leaves LPLC, the
 assessment portfolio will be given to the family if requested.
 
  INFANT SPECIFIC INFORMATION (t)
  ‚Ä¢ Parents must supply the essential items for the child such as: diapers, wipes, diaper cream, food, extra clothing,
  pacifiers, bottles, formula. Please label all items with child‚Äôs first and last name.
  ‚Ä¢ Parents will be notified either through Brightwheel or in person if their child‚Äôs materials need to be replenished ie.
  diapers and wipes.
  ‚Ä¢ Diapers will be checked and changed every 2 hours and changed if needed earlier.
  ‚Ä¢ Each infant up to eighteen (18) months of age who uses a pacifier must have the pacifier offered when being put
  down to sleep, unless the parent directs otherwise.
  ‚Ä¢ Infants must be place on his/her back for sleeping.
  ‚Ä¢ Alternative sleep positions for infants must only be allowed with a health care plan completed and signed by the
  child‚Äôs physician.
  ‚Ä¢ Infants who fall asleep in a car safety seat, bouncy seat, infant seat, swing, feeding chair, play pen or play yard,
  highchair, chair, or other piece of equipment not approved for sleep must immediately be moved to their approved
  sleep area and placed on their back to sleep.
  ‚Ä¢ Children who are awake must not be confined for more than fifteen (15) minutes at a time to cribs, playpens,
  swings, high chairs, infant seats, or other equipment that inhibits freedom of movement. Children who are actively
  eating may be in a high chair or other approved feeding equipment for longer than fifteen (15) minutes. Children
  must be moved away from the feeding location once feeding is complete.
  ‚Ä¢ Supervised tummy time must be offered to infants one month of age or older up to twenty to thirty (20-30) minutes
  per day. If an infant falls asleep during tummy time, they will be immediately placed on their back in approved
  sleeping equipment.
  ‚Ä¢ When staff places infants in approved sleeping equipment for sleep, they must check to ensure that the
  temperature in the room is comfortable for a lightly clothed adult, infants will be checked to ensure that they are
  comfortably clothed (not overheated or sweaty), and that bibs or garments with ties or hoods are removed. LPLC
  provides approved sleep sacks designed for sleep in lieu of blankets if needed for additional warmth or comfort.
  ‚Ä¢ If you are breastfeeding, please discuss with your child‚Äôs teacher when your child should be fed breast milk, and
  when you would like to come in and feed your child.
 
 Breastfeeding Friendly Child Care Family Policy
 Longs Peak Learning Center breastfeeding policy is as follows:
 
 Supportive Environment
  ‚Ä¢ We provide an atmosphere that welcomes breastfeeding families. We support mothers who continue to
  breastfeed their infants/children as they return and continue to work.
  ‚Ä¢ We have a private, designated space (other than the bathroom) available for mothers to breastfeed their children.
  We welcome mothers to breastfeed in the classroom as well.
  ‚Ä¢ We maintain a breastfeeding supportive environment through posting and providing culturally appropriate
  breastfeeding support materials (e.g. pictures, posters, etc.), not including those produced or supplied by
  commercial entities and/or manufactures of infant formula.
  ‚Ä¢ We ‚Äúcheck-in‚Äù with mothers for feedback and ways to continue providing support.
  ‚Ä¢ Staff communicates the infant‚Äôs changing schedule (i.e., feeding, napping, etc.) so a mother can adjust her
  schedule for pumping and/or visiting to feed her infant.
 
 Initial Contact

  ‚Ä¢ We discuss breastfeeding support with all potential new families and share this policy and breastfeeding
  resources with them.
  ‚Ä¢ We work with parents prior to their first day in child care to transition the infant to bottle or cup feedings.
 
  Feeding and Handling Milk
  ‚Ä¢ Staff follows storage and handling of breast milk as defined by Colorado Department of Human Services
  regulations and Colorado Rules and Regulations Governing the Health and Sanitation of Child Care Facilities.
  ‚Ä¢ We discuss with all families how expressed milk is handled at our center.
  ‚Ä¢ Freezer space is available for milk storage.
  ‚Ä¢ Staff informs families on written procedures on the proper way to label and handle breast milk.
  ‚Ä¢ Staff coordinates with parents about the quantity of milk remaining in containers to avoid waste.

  Hi, and thank you for your interest in Baby Steps ChildCare LLC. My address is
  1705 N Charlotte St, Appleton, WI 54911. My hours of operation are 7:30 AM to
  4:30 PM, Monday-Friday. Because I am fully licensed, my first aid and CPR
  certifications are up-to-date. I am not open on weekends. For you to secure a
  spot for your child, a walkthrough interview needs to occur. I am interviewing
  you as much as you are interviewing me during this time. My priority is the
  students I already have enrolled, so if I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a good fit, I will
  let you know. I do not offer sibling discounts because this is a licensed
  in-home daycare and my spots are limited. I require the first week‚Äôs rate to
  be paid upfront to secure a place. That is nonrefundable. Additionally, the
  annual registration fee of $125 needs to be paid. This fee is per child. This
  must be two weeks from the tour date and is non-refundable. Payment is
  accepted via cashier's check, state assistance, or the Brightwheel app. This
  is a comprehensive in-app. You get updates about what your kiddo eats, when
  they eat, when they go to the bathroom, etc. This app can collect payments.
  It‚Äôs very convenient for tax time as everything is in one place, in a
  printable form.
 
  I do accept state subsidies (Wisconsin shares). However, if you are in the
  process of getting approved for state subsidy, that can be a very lengthy
  process. I have seen it take up to 3 months to get approved. All fees must be
  paid on time and in full while you‚Äôre waiting to get approved for subsidy. I
  offer walk-throughs from 3:30 pm-4:30 pm, Monday through Friday. I do not
  offer after-hours or weekend times for walk-throughs. I provide all food, and
  I am part of a federal food program that follows strict regulations for
  nutrition. I teach a curriculum from Funshine and make my individualized
  learning plans to meet the child‚Äôs specific needs. One important thing I‚Äôd
  like to say is that I am a daycare that is fully licensed, and this is my
  business. Think of a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù daycare but just in a house. I am a teacher who
  has extensive training, and I have a degree in early childhood education. I am
  not a babysitter. The children enrolled with me are my highest priority, and
  their safety and education are my job. At the bottom of this email, you will
  find a local resource that helps guardians pay for daycare depoists, plus my
  add on Care.com. Please note that I do not allow any electronic devices like
  phones or tablets (for child entertainment )to be brought at any time. If you
  are interested, please send me the following BEFORE REQUESTING A WALK

Hello REMOVED,
 
 Thank you for your interest in Silverspot for your child. Our school operates
 year-round, starting in mid-August and ending in the last week of July.
 
 As a parent participation school, our member families play an active role in our
 play based, educational community. Families are required to contribute by
 working as classroom aides once a week to ensure our 1:5 ratio. There are also
 other school-related responsibilities like attending monthly meetings and
 assisting with school maintenance. Our school is governed by a board of
 directors elected by the membership each spring. The responsibility of being a
 classroom aide can be fulfilled by any family member, including grandparents,
 aunts, and uncles. We also have current and alumni members who are willing to
 work for a family who needs help with classroom shifts for pay. We are offering
 a non-participation option for full time students to support families who are
 unable to participate in the classroom. We limit it to 5 families a year for
 $1900 a month. At Silverspot, we emphasize the importance of both the child and
 their family, as we believe that a collective effort contributes to the growth
 of our little learners. For the past two decades, we've had the privilege of
 nurturing this approach within the vibrant city of Brisbane.
 
 Our enrollment is currently full for our morning program but we do have room in
 our extended care which runs 1pm-5pm. You are welcome to tour and I have one
 coming up on Monday the 6th at 11:30am or 2pm and you can bring your child with
 you. Once you feel that Silverspot aligns with your family's needs, we'll be
 delighted to provide you with an application. To streamline the enrollment
 process, we utilize the Brightwheel school platform for online submission of
 enrollment and fees. We look forward to meeting you soon and wish you a
 wonderful day ahead!
 
 Kindly,
 
 Diana Ji
 Director
 Silverspot Nursery School

  Application for Child Care Financial Assistance
 To Be Eligible for Assistance, Your Family Must
  ‚Ä¢ Have an accepted service need (reason) for child care.
  ‚Ä¢ Meet the income guidelines.
  ‚Ä¢ Live in Vermont.
 How to Apply
 1. Fully complete this application. Incomplete applications will be returned.
 2. Sign at the bottom of page 10. Use a pen.
 3. Complete any additional forms that are required (e.g., Verification of Employment Form).
 4. Gather copies of required verification documents (e.g., child support order). Originals may
  be returned upon request.
 5. Send your application, along with required documents and forms, to your local Community
  Child Care Support Agency (see list on bottom of page 2). They can help you apply.
 Note: If you get Reach Up, ask your case manager if they can authorize Child Care Financial
 Assistance for you. If they can, you DO NOT have to complete this application.
 What Happens Next
 1. Your local agency will determine your eligibility for assistance based on your need for child
  care, household income, and family size.
 2. If you are eligible, assistance may begin immediately.
 Document Checklist
 Review this list and make sure you send all the required documents and forms.
  ¬£ Education savings account: Send proof of any contributions to a qualified account.
  ¬£ Reason for child care: Complete the required forms and gather the documents required
  to verify the service need for child care.
  ¬£ Child support: Send a copy of any child support order. If you‚Äôre not getting or paying the
  amount on the order, send a 6-12 month payment history from the Office of Child Support.
  ¬£ Household income: Include all documents required to verify all sources of income.
  ¬£ State adoption: If you have an adoption assistance agreement with the State of
  Vermont, send a copy. Income limits may be waived, but you‚Äôll still need to provide
  income information and verification and have a service need (reason) for child care.
 Community Child Care Support Agencies
 Staff in your local agency can:
  ‚Ä¢ Answer your questions about assistance and help you apply.
  ‚Ä¢ Provide copies of any additional forms you need to fill out.
  ‚Ä¢ Help you find a child care provider if you don‚Äôt already have one.

  Welcome to Our Home Preschool and Child Care Family
 
 Program
 
 RNCC cares for children ages six-weeks to five years old. Care is provided Monday through Friday 7:30 am‚Äì 5:30 pm. Child
 Care provided after 5:30 pm will be charged $1.00 per minute per child, unless other arrangements have been agreed upon.
 
 RNCC is a three-teacher team that offers infant care, toddler care and a full preschool program preparing children with
 social and emotions skills, as well as, kindergarten readiness.
 
 Payments/Fees
 
  * Full- Time Care
 
 $287/week Infants 6 weeks ‚Äì 2 years.
 
 $271/week Toddlers 2 years ‚Äì 3 years
 
 $221/week Preschoolers 3 years (& potty trained) ‚Äì 5 years
 
  * Drop-in Care $60/day
 
  * A curriculum fee of $150 per child 1 year old and above is collected each August for curriculum, books and supplies
  for the school year.
 
  * Activity fees may apply for planned field trips throughout the year and are collected at the time of activity or
  field trip.
 
  * An enrollment fee equal to two weeks of care is collected to hold enrollment longer that 3 weeks‚Äô time. This fee
  will secure your enrollment at RNCC and is non-refundable.
 
  * A two-weeks deposit is collected at time of enrollment that is applied to your ending two weeks of care at RNCC.
 
  * Payments are made through direct deposit through Union Bank. Payment plans are set up on an individual basis.
  Payments can be made on a weekly, bi-weekly or monthly schedule and are collected prior to caregiving. If your
  payment schedule needs to be changed, a 30 days‚Äô notice is needed, and a new contract will need to be signed. To
  secure enrollment for your child, payment is due regardless of absences.
 
  * Child care fees are reviewed annually and are subject to an increase according to cost of living increases and/or
  business costs.
 
 Enrollment Policy
 
 E Shape2 very family taking an interest in RNCC is treated with respect and dignity. The first phone conversation will
 determine if the program services meet the needs of the family and determine if an interview should be scheduled to meet
 the provider and tour the program. The initial interview is scheduled to meet the provider and tour the program. The
 parents will receive the family handbook and enrollment papers. At that point, if RNCC is a good fit for your family,
 you will receive the child care contract and an enrollment fee or two-week deposit will be collected to secure your
 enrollment at RNCC. Enrollment positions are not held until an enrollment fee or deposit is received. It is ultimately
 up to the provider to decide if a family is a good fit for the program and the provider will make the final decision on
 if a child is enrolled.
 
 Arrival/Departure:
 
 Please send your children in clothes appropriate for the season. Please do not send toys, food, or drinks in with your
 children. Only authorized persons will be allowed to pick up your children. If there is a change in the person picking
 up your child you may inform me through a phone call or text, a photo ID may be required. If you are present, you are
 solely responsible for the supervision and safety of your child at RNCC.
 
 D Shape3

 aily Schedules
 
 Curriculum
 
 Continuity of care is essential for infants and young children to build strong attachments with adults. This connection
 is important in establishing young children‚Äôs capacity to learn and grow. RNCC provides age-appropriate experiences for
 all children that are planned around the child‚Äôs developmental abilities. The curriculum we use is Gee Whiz and meets
 the criteria of the Nebraska Early Learning Guidelines. These areas of learning are language & literacy. at, science,
 creative arts, social & emotional development, and health & physical development. Our ‚Äúschool year‚Äù runs from September
 to May. In August, a curriculum fee of $150 is collected for each child aged 1 year and over.
 
 Six Core Values at RNCC
 
  * E Shape4 ncourage children as they grow and develop a love for God and his word.
 
  * Support culture differences at RNCC by showing respect and being open-minded to other points of view.
 
  * Guide children in a way that allows them to learn and grow at their own pace.
 
  * Understand that children learn best by using positive hands-on experiences in their daily activities.
 
  * Use positive guidance techniques that encourage children by showing dignity, building self-worth, and supporting
  individual uniqueness.
 
  * Creating partnerships with families by being responsive to their needs and providing support to families to meet the
  needs of the children.
 
 Partnerships with Parents
 
 RNCC is committed to providing an environment where the child, family, and provider work as a team toward individual
 goals resulting in a quality learning environment. Communication between parent and provider is essential to providing
 the best possible care for children. Please notify your provider of any concerns, schedule changes, if your child will
 be dropped off or picked up at a time different than their normal schedule or any other information you think would be
 necessary to share regarding the care or well-being of your child.
 
 Shape5 Partnership Plan
 
 Your provider is committed to:
 
 1. Study and understand her childhood culture and the culture she is made for her own immediate family.
 
 2. Be open-minded about parental comments and behaviors that differ from what she believes. Incorporate parental
 preferences, family values and cultures at RNCC as much as possible.
 
 3. Have casual conversations daily with parents about their child‚Äôs day, providing a daily sheet of the activities done
 each day and scheduling regular meetings with parents to discuss their child‚Äôs care and well-being.
 
 Philosophy of Caring for Young Children
 
 The goal of RNCC is to be responsive to the needs of families by collaborating with them, as well as providing support
 to them to meet the needs of each child. Providing continuity of care, a safe and loving environment and being sensitive
 to individual needs to build trusting relationships with each child. By understanding how children develop and offer
 daily learning experiences to maximize growth for all children. And, to help build self-worth by encouraging children‚Äôs
 involvement in activities and tasks throughout their daily experiences.
 
 Philosophy of Guidance and Discipline
 
 Definition of Discipline: Guidance that helps develop self-control, done with children, focuses on positive learning,
 promotes self-esteem, an active process, often based on preparation or anticipation, focuses on behavior, and encourages
 growth.
 
 RNCC Expectations:
 
 BE KIND: All children are encouraged to be nice to one another and acknowledge others‚Äô feelings.
 
 BE SAFE: All children are encouraged to be safe with their bodies and others around them as they play, use equipment and
 furniture throughout their day.
 
 BE NEAT: All children are encouraged to help with clean-up after playing and other activities done throughout the day
 before moving on to something new.
 
 Infants
 
 I Shape6 nfants are redirected as much as possible without losing sight of the teachable moments the situation poses.
 When an infant is in danger or harming another child, they will be removed from the situation. At this age RNCC focuses
 more on positive behavior rather than unwanted behavior.
 
 Example: An infant is reaching for an outlet, and I would say, ‚ÄúOuch! That will hurt you.‚Äù then take their hand and
 re-direct them to a toy that would allow them to do a similar activity like sticking things in a slot or hole.
 
 Toddlers
 
 Redirection is used as much as possible without losing sight of the teachable moments the situation poses. Continual
 unwanted behavior of a toddler will be managed by removal of the problem toy or object and/or losing the privilege to be
 part of the activity or play that is happening. This may be done by setting the child alone to play by themselves for a
 while or sitting in the safe seat. When a toddler is in danger or harming another child, they will be removed from the
 situation immediately.
 
 Preschoolers
 
 Every child is guided through the day with positive reinforcement in all activities, always encouraged to do their best.
 Unwanted behavior is managed by stating what is seen, helping children recognize their feelings, how to manage them
 appropriately and what they could do differently next time. Focusing on positive behavior helps children gain and keep a
 positive self-image. Aggressive or harmful behavior is managed by removing the child from the situation, allowing the
 child time to ‚Äòcool off‚Äô and then talking about what happened, how they can do better next time and role playing.
 Sitting in the safe seat and/or loss of privileges like playing with others or doing group activities may be necessary
 if a child is not able to be kind to others around them or follow directions.
 
 Nap Time/ Quiet time:
 
 Nap time/quiet time is between the hours of 12:00 pm ‚Äì 2:30 pm. Nap/quiet time is required for all children in care at
 RNCC. Children do not have to fall asleep but are encouraged to have a rest period each day. Please avoid arrival and
 departure during these times. If arrival and/or departure is necessary during nap time hours please make arrangements
 with us ahead of time.
 
 Potty Training:
 
 We are happy to help with potty-training when your child shows signs of potty-training readiness. Some good indications
 of potty-training readiness are, interested in wanting to use the potty, can communicate toileting needs, stays dry for
 longer periods of time (2-3 hours), has a predictable toileting schedule, seems uncomfortable with wet or dirty diapers,
 can pull pants down and up, can follow basic directions.
 
 We ask parents to be 100% on board in helping with potty training to keep things consistent for the child at home and at
 daycare. Parents will need to provide diapers or pull-ups for their children during nap time based on the child‚Äôs needs.
 Children must be accident free for one month, including nap time before wearing underwear alone and be considered
 potty-trained.
 
 Parent Grievance
 
 Every parent of RNCC has the right to express their opinions and concerns regarding all aspects of their involvement
 with the program. RNCC encourages parents to communicate their concerns, as well as review the ‚ÄúParent Handbook for
 Family Child Care Homes‚Äù from the Nebraska Health and Human Services System. RNCC is dedicated to seeking resolution of
 any concern or grievance and to provide the best care possible for each child individually with the child‚Äôs best
 interest in mind.
 
 Holidays
 
 The following are days RNCC is closed with pay:
 
 N Shape7 ew Year‚Äôs Day, Good Friday, Provider Appreciation Day (Friday before Mother‚Äôs Day), Memorial Day, Independence
 Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, Black Friday, December 24^th ‚Äì January 1^st. Holidays that fall on a Saturday will be
 observed on the previous Friday and Holiday‚Äôs that fall on a Sunday will be observed on the following Monday.
 
 Teacher Resource/Training Days
 
 RNCC will be closed the last Friday each month for teacher resource days. Adjustments may be made when resource days
 fall around a holiday. These days will be included on our ‚ÄúDays Off‚Äù Sheet. In addition, if a required training falls on
 a week day, we will be closing so we can attend these training courses. These days will also be listed on the time off
 sheet. Payment will still be collected on these days and alternative care for your children will be required.
 
 Inclement Weather Days
 
 RNCC will be CLOSED for inclement weather following the SCC closings. Inclement Weather Days are when SCC has no classes
 due to the weather conditions. Payment would still be collected for inclement weather days. If SCC closes due to weather
 conditions, I will notify you by posting on our private Facebook page and through our family text threads. You would
 need to find alternative care for your children for that day or stay safe and warm in your homes.
 
 Vacation
 
 We close for one week each year for family vacation and tuition is still collected. We try to plan out our vacation days
 at least six months at a time or for the whole year, if possible, to give you as much time as we can to make alternate
 child care arrangements and/or plan your vacation at the same time. We will provide you with a ‚ÄúDays off sheet‚Äù at the
 beginning of each calendar year. Any adjustment to the DOS will be given with at least a 30-day notice.
 
 Funeral Leave
 
 One to five paid days for funeral leave is given in the case of the death of a member of my immediate family or close
 friend. This includes my spouse, children, parents, siblings, grandchildren, the spouse of any of these relatives, or a
 person who was similarly related to my spouse (in-laws) and close friends. Depending on when funeral arrangements are
 made, travel time, etc. The number of days will be determined at the time of need. But God willing, we do not have to
 worry about such things.
 
 Substitute Care
 
 I Shape8 n the event your provider needs to be away from the child care premises, RNCC will do their best to provide a
 substitute caregiver for the care of your child. Substitute caregivers are designated people that are approved by the
 Nebraska Child Care Licensing Department. Meeting substitute caregivers can be arranged by request. Substitute
 caregivers have a background check and are approved by DHHS for the safety of your child. Notices will be given when a
 substitute is used in place of Robin.
 
 Meals
 
 R Shape9 NCC provides breakfast, AM snack, lunch, and PM snacks that meet or exceed the guidelines of the Family Service
 Food Program. RNCC offers Target brand formula for infants up to twelve months of age. If your infant requires a special
 kind of formula, you may provide that for your infant. RNCC will provide infants aged 8 months up to their first
 birthday with pureed fruits & vegetables in addition to their formula. Individual food plans will be made between the
 parents and RNCC. Please do not send food with your child unless you have a child on a special diet with a doctor‚Äôs note
 or are bringing snacks for everyone. Prayer is encouraged at meal times.
 
 Emergency Plans
 
 *For life-threatening emergencies, the provider will call 911 and the parents.
 
 *Severe weather; the provider will take children to laundry room in the basement and await direction from local weather
 specialists to determine when it is safe to resume normal activities. Six tornado drills are practiced each year.
 
 *Poison; the Provider will call poison control and the parents.
 
 * Shape10 Fire; the Provider will gather children, exit out the nearest door, and walk together across the street to our
 safe spot (Gary‚Äôs Tree), then the provider will call 911 and the parents. Twelve fire drills are practiced each year.
 
 Authorized Escort
 
 For the safety of your child, please let RNCC know if you plan to have someone other than yourself or authorized persons
 pick-up your child from daycare. RNCC will not allow anyone to pick up your child without your consent. At the first
 pick up of an unknown person, they will be required to show their ID so we can match that to the names on their list of
 people cleared for pick up.
 
 Transportation
 
 A Shape11 ll children being transported while in care at RNCC will use seat belts and/or use the appropriate car seat
 for their ages. Prior notification will be given for planned outings, and you will be asked to leave your child‚Äôs car
 seats in the morning. Please be sure your child has the correct car seat for their weight and age. It is RNCC
 responsibility as a child care professional to protect the safety of your child when in my care, as well as, leaving my
 care.
 
 Immunizations
 
 RNCC is required by the State of Nebraska to submit a statement certifying each child‚Äôs immunization records and to keep
 accurate up-to-date records in each child‚Äôs file. Please provide RNCC with a list of new immunizations as they occur.
 
 Supplies
 
 Personal items that your child is asked to bring to RNCC are:
 
  * D Shape12 iapers and/or pull-ups and Wipes.
 
  * 3 Bottles, if needed.
 
  * Pacifier, if needed.
 
  * Lotions, creams, sunscreens, and powders that you want for your child.
 
  * Change of clothes (especially needed during toilet training).
 
  * Blanket and pillow for naptime.
 
  * Appropriate hats, coats, foot ware for each season.
 
 We have a play-based program, this includes a lot of outside play time. Children can get messy when they play, please
 dress your children appropriately to allow children to play without restrictions.
 
 Child Abuse and Neglect
 
 It is the goal of RNCC to protect the health and safety of all children in this program. We are mandatory reporters and
 are required by law to report any suspicions of child abuse or neglect. You, as a parent, are also required by law to
 report any suspicions of child abuse or neglect. Effective communication between parents and provider is essential.
 
 Medications: Shape13
 
 RNCC does not administer medications unless it is required for medical needs such as asthma or severe food allergies. A
 separate agreement will be made for these kinds of situations and a doctor‚Äôs note is required. The following policy will
 be followed. Prescription and over-the-counter medicine to be administered by RNCC must be signed in the medication
 record, stating the times, amount of medicine to be given and how often your child needs to receive the medication. All
 medicine provided must be in the original container, clearly labeled with the child‚Äôs full name and directions for the
 proper amount (dosage) and times to be administered. Please be sure labels are readable and have the right doses listed
 for your child‚Äôs specific age.
 
 Exclusion Policy
 
 If the provider‚Äôs own children become ill, RNCC will contact you as early as possible for you to pick them up and find
 alternative childcare for that day. Ill children must be picked up within an hour.
 
 R Shape14 NCC has the responsibility to keep the spreading of illness to a minimum. RNCC consistently enforce our Health
 Policy.
 
 Children are excluded from daycare for the following symptoms:
 
  * Fever of 100.2 degrees or more (auxiliary reading/under the arm then add one degree for accuracy).
 
  * Vomiting.
 
  * Undiagnosed rash.
 
  * Draining of ears or open sores.
 
  * Any symptoms of possible infectious disease (such as red goopy eyes).
 
  * Two watery stools in a 24-hour period, or one uncontained bout.
 
  * A deep or chesty, or croupy, or constant cough, or wheezing
 
  * Mouth sores with drooling.
 
  * Misery with a cold. Including goopy, watery eyes, running nose, sore throat, or other physical symptoms.
 
  * Inability to cope in group situation because of not feeling well or feeling ‚Äúunder the weather.‚Äù
 
 Children need to stay home from daycare until:
 
  * Fever free for 24 hours without medication: 48 hours if they had more than one symptom.
 
  * Able to eat solids without vomiting.
 
  * Bowel movements must continue to be solid when returning.
 
  * 24 hours after the first dose of medication taken due to contagious illnesses with symptoms improving and no
  fever.
 
  The final decision whether to exclude a child from care is made by the child care provider.
 
 Notices
 
 A 30-day notice is required for the following:
 
 1. Termination of agreement by either party following the completion of a trial period. (In the case of violent, vulgar
 behavior toward the provider of either parent or child services will be terminated immediately.)
 
 2. Increases in payments and/or fees or change in payment schedule.
 
 3. Vacation time.
 
 4. New policies in the Parent Handbook.
 
 Shape15

 2. References are requested for families seeking enrollment at RNCC.

 Ethical Society Nursery School
 
 IMMUNIZATION POLICY
 
 State law requires that every child enrolled in a nursery school, preschool,
 or day care center must be adequately immunized according to the
 REMOVEDouri Immunization Schedule. This schedule is in compliance with the
 U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease
 Control and Prevention, The AmREMOVEDn Academy of Pediatrics, and The
 AmREMOVEDn Academy of Family Physicians. For more information about
 required immunizations visit:
 
 https://health.mo.gov/living/wellness/immunizations/schoolrequirements.php
 
 Each parent must provide satisfactory evidence of required immunizations
 to the director who, in turn, must file an annual report of compliance. Your
 child‚Äôs pediatrician provides a report of vaccinations to you at each visit,
 and a copy of this form is adequate evidence of vaccination. Immunization
 information, signed by the child's doctor (by hand or electronically), must be
 on file in the Nursery School office before a child is allowed to enter
 school.
 
 The Ethical Society Nursery School Board will review cases of necessary
 medical exemptions and will potentially allow an unvaccinated child to
 attend school. Any other exemption to vaccinations is not allowed.
 
 Children who are on a delayed immunization schedule are required to
 submit the REMOVEDouri Department of Health ‚ÄúImmunizations in Progress‚Äù form
 with their immunization record. The Board will then review the child‚Äôs record
 and decide on eligibility to continue. (see statute below)
 Immunization in progress. Section 167.181, RSMo, provides that students may continue to attend
 school as long as they have started an immunization series and provide satisfactory evidence
 indicating progress is being accomplished. An original Department of Health and Senior
 Services‚Äô form Imm.P.14 shall be completed and placed on file with the school immunization
 health record of each student with immunizations in progress. The Imm.P.14 form is
 incorporated by reference in this rule as published June 2012 by the Department of Health and
 Senior Services and may be obtained by contacting a medical provider, local public health
 agency, or the department‚Äôs Bureau of Immunization Assessment and Assurance at PO Box 570,
 Jefferson City, MO 65102-0570, or by calling 800-219-3224. This rule does not incorporate any
 subsequent amendments or additions. Failure to meet the next scheduled appointment constitutes
 noncompliance with the school immunization law and exclusion shall be initiated immediately.
 
 Policy approved by ESNS Board 12/5/2018

  Connection with The Ethical Society of Saint Louis
 
  ESNS was started in 1968 by members of the Society as a way of supporting children and
  families. Although we are not managed by the Society, we do agree and align with their core
  values as listed below:
 
 ‚óè Every person is important and unique.
 ‚óè Every person deserves to be treated fairly and kindly.
 ‚óè We can learn from everyone.
 ‚óè We are part of this earth; We cherish it and all the life upon it.
 ‚óè We learn from the world around us by using our senses, mind, and feelings.
 ‚óè We are members of the world community, which depends on the cooperation of all people for
  peace and justice.
 ‚óè We can learn from the past to build for the future.
 ‚óè We are free to question.
 ‚óè We are free to choose what we believe.
 ‚óè We accept responsibility for our choices and actions.
 ‚óè We strive to live our values.
 
  Families who wish to join the Society‚Äôs email newsletter should contact the ESNS director.
  Please see ethicalstl.org for more information
 
  1
 TABLE OF CONTENTS
