 Board of Directors
 
 2
  School Operations
 
 School Hours
 
 School hours are 8:45 am-11:45 am for all classes.
 
 The Yellow and Blue Room children attend school Monday through Friday. The 2 Day Green
 Room children are at school on Tuesday and Thursday. The 3 Day Green Room children attend
 Monday, Wednesday and Friday mornings.
 
 Visiting School
 
 Parents are a very important part of our school community and are welcome to visit school at
 any time.
 
 Lunch Bunch and Early Morning Care
 
 Lunch is offered everyday from 11:45 am until 2:15 p.m. Parents should send lunch and a drink
 with their student. The children will eat lunch together, and participate in free play and
 organized activities. They will also spend time outside on the playground, weather permitting.
 
 There is a discounted rate to the families that utilize the program more often. Please email
 staciezd@gmail.com if you are interested in signing up for Lunch Bunch.
 
 Early morning care starts at 8:15 a.m. and is offered every day.
 
 Drop Off and Pick Up Procedure
 
 In the interest of the children‚Äôs safety, parents and caregivers must use the following driving
 pattern when dropping off or picking up a student.
 
  1 All cars will enter via the WEST driveway.
  2 FOR THE YELLOW and BLUE ROOMS - Cars will then pull up next to the hedge that
  runs along the patio to meet the director/teacher for drop off or pick up.
  3 FOR THE GREEN ROOM ‚Äì Cars will continue to the driveway leading up the EAST side
  of the building and stop at the gate to the steps to the patio.
  4 The passenger side of the car will be adjacent to the patio/porch sidewalk. Place the
  car in ‚ÄúPARK.‚Äù The director/teacher will open the passenger rear side door to help
  children in or out of the car.
  5 Cars will then pull forward and exit via the EAST driveway.
 
 At dismissal time, in order to keep the line moving as quickly as possible, please pull forward,
 adjacent to the playground, to buckle children‚Äôs seatbelts before exiting via the EAST driveway.
 
 3
 If parents wish to come into the school, they may park and escort their child across the parking
 lot, holding hands, to ensure their safety in the parking lot. We also ask that you stay OFF YOUR
 CELL PHONES in the parking lot. We all need to focus on student safety.
 
 Parents who find that they will be delayed in picking up their child are asked to call the school or
 text the director. Some children need reassurance and may become anxious when they see their
 friends leave while they are still waiting. We may take a child who is waiting to be picked up to
 the Lunch Bunch area to play with friends.
 
 Authorization to Leave School
 
 Please email the director, every time they are to go home with someone who does not usually
 drive them. This adult may be asked to provide identification. To ensure children‚Äôs safety, ESNS
 will not release a child to any individual without written permission from a parent.
 
 Snow Days / School Closings
 
 If driving is hazardous and it is necessary to close school, the director will send out a message
 on the Class Dojo messaging platform and send an email.
 
 The driveway at the Society can become slick and dangerous in cases of icy weather. If the
 Society closes for this reason, we must cancel school, and you will be notified as stated above.
 In the past, the building has been closed for water main breaks and lack of heat in the winter.
 The director will do her best to keep you informed and updated via text reminders, email and
 notifications on Class DoJo.
 
 Sickness
 
 ** If a child is not well, keep them home for their own sake and that of the other children. Per
 State requirements, we will not accept a sick child in our care. **
 
 We all want to keep children and teachers healthy. Please keep your child home when they:
 
  ‚óè Have a fever or have had one during the previous 24 hours. A child should be fever free,
  without medication, for 24 hours before returning to school.
  ‚óè Have a severe new cold with heavy nasal discharge or a constant cough.
  ‚óè Are vomiting or have diarrhea.
  ‚óè Need to be given medicine while at school.
  ‚óè Are fussy, cranky, or exceptionally fatigued.
 
 We will follow CDC Covid guidelines. Please keep your child home for five days if they test
 positive for Covid and then they should wear a mask for five days. Teachers will follow the same
 guidelines. If we are all respectful and follow these rules we hopefully will not have to close a
 
 4
 classroom or the school down for an outbreak. We encourage everyone to stay up to date with
 Covid vaccinations. Any part of our COVID-19 Policy Information can be changed or updated at
 any time by the Board of Trustees.
 
 Please call or email when a child is sick. In turn, the school will inform parents of communicable
 diseases present in the different classrooms. A parent will be contacted if a child becomes sick
 at school and if they cannot be reached, the school will telephone the emergency contacts who
 have been designated for such a situation.
 
 Healthy procedures
 
 Hand-washing for all children is scheduled into the morning, beginning with drop-off.
 
 Teachers supervise children using hand sanitizer. Hand sanitizer is available in all classrooms,
 at the doorway to the office, and at health screening stations during drop off.
 
 ESNS continues to follow the state standards and protocols for cleaning, sanitizing, and
 disinfecting in an early childhood setting. The state required methods of cleaning and sanitizing
 is done before and after children eat at the classroom tables as well as when children use the
 tables for centers.
 
 Accidents/Injuries
 
 Each parent must grant authorization to the school to provide emergency medical care. If there
 is an accident and a child is injured, there will be an immediate attempt to contact the parent. If
 neither parent can be reached, the school will call the child‚Äôs pediatrician. In cases of serious
 injury or health crisis, 911 will be called first and parents second.
 Please keep the school informed of any changes in home, cell, or work telephone numbers or
 those of emergency contacts.
 
 Clothing
 
 ESNS encourages exploration and experiential learning which may include things like finger
 painting, mixing substances that have been dyed with food coloring, or hiking through the
 muddy woods at the bottom of the parking lot. Any number of activities may cause clothing to
 get dirty or stained. Please send your child in washable, sturdy play clothes. If possible, please
 label your child‚Äôs clothing.
 Children take care of themselves by pulling on/off their own shoes, jackets, or clothing to use
 the bathroom or change into dry clothes if there is a wet accident. This fosters independence
 and self-sufficiency. Children feel proud of themselves when they can take care of themselves in
 this manner and are capable of this responsibility. When considering clothing for school, avoid
 belts, overalls, dressy outfits, or items your child cannot begin to maneuver themselves.
 Outside play is very important for children. ESNS plays outdoors every day except when the
 weather is extremely cold or rainy. In winter, please send warm clothing. Layers work best.
 
 5
 Gloves, jackets, hats, and mittens should be labeled. It is better to have it and not need it than
 need it and not have it.
 
 Toys From Home
 
 Toys or possessions from home often make children feel more comfortable in the less familiar
 environment at school. Children in the Green Room programs are welcome to bring a ‚Äúlovey‚Äù
 from home that may live in their backpack while at school. Blankets or a stuffed animal can be
 cuddled and kept safe in a backpack. Pacifiers should be left at home.
 In some classrooms, children get to bring a show-and-share item. Please avoid sending
 breakable or precious objects. Weapons, such as guns, sharp or pointed toys, umbrellas, money,
 gum or candy are not appropriate for school and will be kept in the office with the director until
 dismissal time. Visits from pets are very much enjoyed but please inform teachers ahead of
 time.
 
  Celebrations and Parent Involvement
 
 Classroom Snacks
 Mid-morning snacks are served each day and the school very much appreciates the nutritious
 snacks that parents provide. Snacks form a special connection between home and the
 classroom.
 ESNS shares parents‚Äô concerns about healthy food options and the need to avoid snacks with
 excess sugar, fat, or salt. Fresh fruit, vegetables, crackers, cheese, and muffins are preferable to
 cupcakes and cookies. Water is served with each snack.
 The director will communicate any food allergies at the beginning of the school year. Parents are
 asked to try to accommodate these allergies in snack selection and send enough snacks to feed
 all of the children in the classroom.
 Please sign up to bring snacks on the calendar or through the Class Dojo.
 
 Birthday Celebrations
 Birthdays are special occasions here at ESNS. The birthday child is the snack provider for the
 class on their special day. Small cupcakes or cookies can serve to mark the occasion. Half
 birthdays are celebrated for those with summer birthdays. Teachers will consult with parents if
 a birthday falls on the weekend or over a school break.
 Please do not send goodie bags, balloons or candy. We keep it simple here at ESNS.
 Sometimes a student‚Äôs family will donate a book to ESNS‚Äôs library to commemorate their
 birthday. Should you wish to do so, teachers can help with book suggestions or whether we
 already have your child‚Äôs favorite in our library. Parents are welcome to visit the classroom and
 read a birthday book. Please consult with your child‚Äôs teacher to determine the best time of day
 for a book reading.
 
 6
 Holiday Celebrations
 Celebrations are a vital part of our culture and ESNS children enjoy special activities for
 birthdays and many holidays: Halloween, Thanksgiving Day, Martin Luther King Day, Valentine‚Äôs
 Day, Presidents‚Äô Day, and the Fourth of July. Children make gifts as a means of sharing and
 ‚Äútaking care of‚Äù someone else. Most of these holidays fit into our ‚Äútaking care of‚Äù model which
 encourages acceptance and understanding of different backgrounds, religions, and cultures.
 ESNS holds a simple Holiday Party before winter break with singing and food to share.
 
 ESNS Community Gatherings
 
 Several social gatherings are scheduled during the school year including a Back to School/Open
 House for families and teachers in October and monthly Picnic on the Playground when the
 weather is nice. Younger children are invited. Other community events including a Movie Night,
 Grandparents Day, the Spring Carnival, and the Art Gallery Opening serve to bring families
 together, strengthen classroom friendships, and put faces to names.
 
 Historically, at the end of the school day, families have allowed their children to play on school
 grounds. We love that students and families want to spend more time at our school and we
 want to do so safely while respecting the wishes of The Ethical Society. Families are encouraged
 to choose play areas that are safe and in the north part of the grounds away from traffic and
 stained glass windows. The Ethical Woods at the bottom of the parking lot is an excellent
 choice.
 
 Parent-Teacher Conferences
 
 Parent-teacher conferences are scheduled twice each year, in the fall and spring.
 In addition, a conference can be held at any time, initiated by parents or teachers to discuss a
 common concern or to share news affecting the life of the student.
 Parents and teachers may also exchange information by email, phone, or through our sharing
 platform Class Dojo. Parents are also encouraged to email or message teachers to arrange a
 time to discuss their child. To ensure privacy, it is best to avoid discussing concerns in the
 classroom when children or other parents are present.
 
 Resource Library
 ESNS has a parent resource library in the bookshelf outside the preschool door. This includes
 books on parenting and child development, pamphlets and flyers from elementary school
 programs, and special classes or events. We will also post articles or information about child
 centered events in our area on Class DoJo.
 Please feel welcome to borrow books and materials any time.
 
 7
 Fundraising Activities
 
 Fundraising projects provide necessary support to the ESNS budget. We typically have a Fall
 Fundraiser Event that has included past activities such as a wine-tasting and a silent auction.
 In the spring, our child-centered carnival provides a community building event for our families.
 These events usually include auctions, raffles, and much more.
 Parent support in the organization and success of these fundraisers is tremendously appreciated
 and could not happen without your effort.
 
 The Ellen Schapiro Scholarship Fund
 We solicit funds that are used as tuition assistance for families who might otherwise be unable
 to afford our program. Named for our beloved former director, all donations are tax deductible.
 When children practice positive social skills and start to build their ‚Äúintellectual scaffolding,‚Äù
 they are more likely to succeed in meeting behavioral expectations in kindergarten and beyond.
 ESNS helps construct an academic foundation and a love for learning by supporting children‚Äôs
 natural curiosity in an age appropriate manner. All children can benefit from this style of
 preschool programming and The Ellen Schapiro Scholarship Fund ensures that everyone can.
 
  School Policies and Procedures
 
 Tuition
 
 Tuition is billed monthly through our Quickbooks accounting program. You will receive an email
 invoice at the first of the month that is due upon receipt. Parents may pay on a semester,
 monthly or annual payment plan. Charges for Extended Day are also billed monthly. Please
 discuss payment options with the director. Payments can be made on-line with debit cards. We
 also accept cash and checks made out to The Ethical Society Nursery School.
 
 Withdrawal Policy
 
 ESNS has many ongoing expenses such as teacher salaries, rent, and custodial fees. As per your
 enrollment agreement letter, it should be understood that enrollment is a commitment for the
 entire academic year. No reduction or remission of fees can be allowed in the event of a child‚Äôs
 withdrawal from school.
 
 Immunizations
 
 State law requires that every child enrolled in a nursery school, preschool, or day care center
 must be adequately immunized according to the REMOVEDouri Immunization Schedule. This schedule
 is in compliance with the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease
 Control and Prevention, The AmREMOVEDn Academy of Pediatrics, and The AmREMOVEDn Academy of
 
 8
 Family Physicians. For more information about required immunizations
 visit:https://health.mo.gov/living/wellness/immunizations/schoolrequirements.php
 Each parent must provide satisfactory evidence of required immunizations to the director who,
 in turn, must file an annual report of compliance. Your child‚Äôs pediatrician provides a report of
 vaccinations to you at each visit, and a copy of this form is adequate evidence of vaccination.
 Immunization information, signed by the child's doctor (by hand or electronically), must be on
 file in the Nursery School office before a child is allowed to enter school.
 The Ethical Society Nursery School Board will review cases of necessary medical exemptions and
 will potentially allow an unvaccinated child to attend school. Any other exemption to
 vaccinations is not allowed.
 Children who are on a delayed immunization schedule are required to submit the REMOVEDouri
 Department of Health ‚ÄúImmunizations in Progress‚Äù form with their immunization record. The
 Board will then review the child‚Äôs record and decide on eligibility to continue. (see statute
 below)
 
 Immunization in progress. Section 167.181, RSMo, provides that students may continue to
 attend school as long as they have started an immunization series and provide satisfactory
 evidence indicating progress is being accomplished. An original Department of Health and
 Senior Services‚Äô form Imm.P.14 shall be completed and placed on file with the school
 immunization health record of each student with immunizations in progress. The Imm.P.14
 form is incorporated by reference in this rule as published June 2012 by the Department of
 Health and Senior Services and may be obtained by contacting a medical provider, local public
 health agency, or the department‚Äôs Bureau of Immunization Assessment and Assurance at PO
 Box 570, Jefferson City, MO 65102-0570, or by calling 800-219-3224. This rule does not
 incorporate any subsequent amendments or additions. Failure to meet the next scheduled
 
 9
 appointment constitutes noncompliance with the school immunization law and exclusion shall
 be initiated immediately.
 
 Immunization Policy approved by ESNS Board 12/5/2018
 
 Discipline/Setting Limits
 ESNS follows an umbrella policy on discipline. Each class models the ‚Äútaking care of‚Äù goals for
 working in a community.
 ‚ÄúTaking care of ourselves; taking care of each other; taking care of our community.‚Äù
 Taking care of ourselves covers everything from washing our hands before we eat to verbally
 expressing our desire for someone else‚Äôs toy with polite words. Taking care of each other
 involves watching our own body in space so we don‚Äôt bump into or knock over anyone else to
 taking turns on the slide so everyone gets to play. We take care of our community by recycling,
 cleaning up after ourselves, and treating our community toys gently.
 Our teachers have years of experience in anticipating outbursts or unhealthy peer interactions.
 In most cases, we can stop or redirect behavior before something negative occurs. If not,
 teachers will first consult with the injured party to make sure they are emotionally and
 physically okay. Then, they will turn their attention to the child who might need more support in
 ‚Äútaking care of our friends‚Äù or, more likely, ‚Äútaking care of ourselves‚Äù in a positive manner.
 Reflection over what has occurred will lead to discovering other behavior options, usually an
 apology and finally a do-over. Modeling healthy peer interactions is what we do best, every day.
 Setting reasonable limits for children is predicated on ESNS‚Äôs deeply held beliefs:
  ‚óè Children need predictable limits so they can behave freely and responsibly within secure
  boundaries.
  ‚óè Limits are set to ensure the safety of all children.
  ‚óè No child may hurt another child nor will the teachers allow this to occur.
  ‚óè Under no circumstances will physical force or punishment be used on any child.
 Procedures:
  ‚óè Positive reinforcement.
  ‚óè Anticipating unhealthy social interactions.
  ‚óè Redirection. Encouraging positive, healthy, and inclusive social activities.
  ‚óè Expressing disappointment or disapproval in a respectful and constructive manner.
  ‚óè Simple, logical, and immediate consequences.
 
 If you have any questions about this policy of setting limits and ‚Äútaking care of each other,‚Äù
 please speak with the director.
 
 ESNS Board of Directors
 
 10
 The Board of Directors is the governing body of the Ethical Society Nursery School whose
 members include:
 
 The director of the Ethical Society Sunday School
 The director of the Nursery School (non-voting)
 At least five parents of ESNS students
 At least four additional friends of ESNS making at least eleven ESNS Board members (at least 10
 voting members.)
 
 The Board is responsible for the overall management of ESNS: establishing school policy,
 formulating the budget, organizing fundraising activities, determining staff salaries, and
 selecting a director.
 
 Thank you for reading the entire Handbook. Please let us know if you have any questions.

 First a little about our school, we open at 7:30 AM and close at 4:00 PM, we
 offer an after school program to parents that is an extra $50.00 a week and is
 from 4:00 to 6:00 PM. We are an Early Intervention Day Treatment Facility that
 offers Speech, Physical, and Occupational Therapies at the school! We have a
 developmental specialist to aide staff in correct developmental practices in our
 classrooms. Do you have concerns with your childs development? For example, any
 concerns with speech? How does he/she run, climb, jump? Does she/he have
 Medicaid A? If so you can contact your childs PCP and ask them to perform a
 developmental screener for a possible delay. If the PCP says yes they have a
 possible delay, then you can have a referral for developmental, speech,
 occupational, and physical evaluations to see if they might qualify for therapy
 and if so then Medicaid will pay for your childs attendance.
 We also accept private pay and for her age group we charge $110.00 a week, with
 an $85.00, one time enrollment fee, and payment is due the week before she
 attends.
 We provide breakfast, lunch and snack that meets the USDA federal meal time
 guidelines.

 facility just let me know what works best for you! And will let you know
 Monday, for sure about available spots.

 Batesville, AR 72501

 students I already have enrolled, so if I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a good fit, I will

 registration fee of $125 needs to be paid. This fee is per child. This must be
 two weeks from the tour date and is non-refundable. Payment is accepted via
 cashier's check, state assistance, or the Brightwheel app. This is a
 comprehensive in-app. You get updates about what your kiddo eats, when they eat,
 when they go to the bathroom, etc. This app can collect payments. It‚Äôs very
 convenient for tax time as everything is in one place, in a printable form.

Hello REMOVED,
 Thanks for your interest in Blue Oak Creative Schoolhouse. We are sorry to hear
 you are having an unanticipated search for childcare. We know how anxious a
 process that can be. We are a year-round full-day preschool program, with our
 school year beginning in August. While our school year is already underway, we
 have two spaces available for immediate enrollment.
 We would love to have you join us for a tour to see if our school may be a good
 fit for your family. Touring is the first step in our application process, and
 we do require both/all custodial parents to attend a tour before we can proceed
 with enrolling a child. We typically offer tours on a monthly basis, rotating
 location. Since all of our campuses share the same teaching philosophy and
 approach, we do not require parents to tour their preferred location in order to
 apply. Tours are for adults only, and parents are welcome to tour on separate
 dates if need be; we will provide the application after the first parent
 completes the tour. We actually have a tour TODAY at 10 am at our Washington
 Campus since we are trying to fill the two available spaces as soon as possible.
 If you are able to join, please let me know so we can plan accordingly.
 Otherwise, you can register for another tour or join our tour interest list to
 be notified when more tour dates are added via the link below.
 
 Blue Oak Tour Registration Form
 
 Please note that if you attend a tour, but wish to see another campus in person,
 we do not offer private walk-throughs or tours; however, we welcome you to
 register and come at the beginning of the next tour at that campus to see the
 physical space (you do not need to stay for the duration of the tour if you have
 already completed one).
 
 Please feel free to reach out with any additional questions. Otherwise, we hope
 to meet you in the near future.
 
 Best wishes,
 Siobhan
